passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). Approximately 40 to 50 million people died during the Spanish Flu pandemic of 1918, all due to a parasite that is one-millionth of an inch long. As a ubiquitous part of our environment, this organism can only be seen with the aid of an electron microscope, yet it can wreak havoc on the cells of all living organisms. This parasite is called a virus.

(2). A virion is a virus particle that consists of genetic instructions wrapped in a coat of protein. Their genes consist of either DNA or RNA that is protected by a coat of protein. This coat protects their genetic information and aids in detecting the appropriate host cells to invade. Some viruses are surrounded by a lipid membrane, and some are not. The former is called an enveloped virus, and the latter is called a naked virus. These parasites do not have enzymes to carry out their chemical reactions and are entirely dependent on a host to make copies of themselves. Hosts include plants, bacteria, archaea, and animals. Because they don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their functions, they also have the advantage of laying dormant for years as they wait for a host cell to aid them in reproduction.

(3). There are two ways for a virus to reproduce. The first one, used by the common cold and flu viruses, is called the lytic cycle. As soon as the virus enters the host organism, the protein on the virus coat detects the appropriate host cell to invade. It then inserts itself into the wall of the host cell and releases its genetic material inside. This injected genetic material then utilizes the host’s metabolic processes and recruits the enzymes of the host cell to begin making new DNA or RNA strands along with new proteins for the outer wall. As soon as this is complete, the new particles assemble. They then break free either by lysis, which refers to the destruction of the cell or by budding, in which the new virions pinch out of the cell membrane and then carry a piece of the existing membrane with them. Now that there are more virions, they can spread and continue through a new lytic cycle.\

(4). As the virions multiply and spread, the body’s immune response is often triggered and produces pyrogens. This response causes the body’s temperature to rise to induce a fever, which, in turn, causes metabolic processes in the body to slow down. Normally the human body functions most efficiently at 37°C. A higher temperature causes the processes to slow down, slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells.

(5). The other cycle of multiplication is called the lysogenic cycle. This cycle is utilized by viruses that cause herpes and HIV. At the beginning of this cycle, the viruses invade the host’s cells, but they do not multiply. Instead, they mix their genes with the genes of the host so that when the host cell reproduces, the virus’s genetics are copied into the host cell’s offspring. They then often lie dormant until some environmental or genetic event triggers them, causing them to enter the lytic cycle and spread. Therefore, patients with HIV tend not to show symptoms of illness for years after contracting the virus, although the host is still contagious during this time. Perhaps the most infamous exemplification of this process occurred when Magic Johnson, a global icon at the time, announced his HIV-positive status in 1991. The news shocked the sports world and brought powerful awareness overnight.

(6). Johnson’s choice to go public with his HIV diagnosis was impactful for numerous reasons. In 1991, when Johnson made his announcement, those with HIV were often at the center of condemnation. It was a disease that much of the public believed was limited to marginalized communities and was also thought of as leading to a certain death since there existed no cure for the illness at the time. Johnson, being a high-profile celebrity and beloved sports figure, effectively challenged many people’s notions of HIV in terms of who it can impact. The athlete’s announcement humanized the disease in the eyes of many, leading to discussions surrounding prevention, testing, and treatment becoming much more commonplace. Johnson received significant praise for his decision to publicly announce his diagnosis and continues to advocate for reduced stigma of HIV, demonstrating that it is possible to live a full and healthy life as an HIV-positive individual.

(7). Viruses spread through many different means. They can use a carrier organism such as a mosquito or a fly to invade their next host, or they can travel through the air; or can transfer through direct contact of bodily fluids including blood, saliva, semen, vaginal fluid, sweat, or nasal discharge.

(8). Even though viruses cannot carry out their life cycle without a host, they are still susceptible to the same evolutionary pressures that affect other organisms precisely because they rely on other living organisms. If they are to successfully multiply and spread to new hosts, they must carry genes that allow this to happen. If they house genes that do not allow them to multiply effectively, perhaps killing the host within a few hours, those specific genes will disappear forever. On the other hand, if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.

(9). As part of the evolutionary arms race, host bodies busily create antibodies that can detect known viruses and lock them into their outer protein surface, thus preventing them from entering the host’s cells. When a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies, and the virus is suddenly successful. It will again be able to quickly multiply while the host’s body is busy trying to recognize the new virus and create the appropriate antibodies.

(10). Viruses can make millions of copies of themselves in seconds, which means that their mutation rate is much higher than in an organism that reproduces much more slowly. However, there is a difference in mutation rates between RNA virions and DNA virions. Viruses with DNA are more stable due to a proofreading check, which they have as part of their reproduction process. These virions use the host cell to check their DNA replication. If there is a mistake in the reproductive process, the host cell is often able to correct it. Therefore, viruses containing DNA do not mutate as frequently as RNA viruses. Two known RNA viruses include the influenza virus and the Human Immunodeficiency Virus, or HIV. As a result, these two viruses are of particular interest to scientists.

(11). When a person receives a vaccination, a small amount of virus is injected into their body, allowing the person’s immune system to create antibodies before they are exposed to the virus from the natural environment. Once they are exposed to the virus, the pre-existing antibodies will be able to quickly recognize and protect the person against the known virus before it can invade. However, RNA viruses such as the influenza virus, which causes the flu, have a high rate of mutation, which means that each year scientists must predict likely mutations in the flu virus to develop an effective vaccination.

(12). There are three types of influenza virus: A, B, and C. Type A influenza virus could infect an array of organisms including humans, pigs, dogs, horses, and birds. Along with the fact that it is an RNA virus, this wide range of hosts means that it has more possibility for mutations. Mutations in influenza virus A are limited to the virus’ surface proteins: hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. You may have heard of the H1N1 strain that caused a pandemic in 2009. The name H1N1 refers to mutations in these two proteins. In contrast, influenza virus types B and C are not able to infect other species, and therefore their mutation rate is much slower.

(13). There are two ways in which these proteins can mutate. The first is by antigenic drift, which refers to mutations in the genetic code as a virus reproduces within a cell. The genetic code of an ancestral virus drifts as it accumulates mutations in its proteins. When scientists develop flu shots, they aim to predict the accumulation of mutations in the coming flu season. Sometimes scientists can predict with some accuracy, and other times they may miss altogether.

(14). The second is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus. Because this strain is so dissimilar from either parent virus, it is difficult for the host’s immune system to detect. If this new virus is successful at reproducing and spreading, it could lead to a pandemic.

(15). Because influenza A can infect different species, it has more opportunities to mutate or recombine and create new strains of the virus. If the pig flu and the human flu enter the same host cell in a bird, they may recombine and create a dramatically different type of influenza strain. If this new strain mutates and spreads in a given organism, it has devastating potential. In 2003, the H5N1 strain, or bird flu, scared many people in that it was drastically different from previous strains. Had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by human immune systems. However, this strain did not spread easily among humans and thus, did not turn into a pandemic.

(16). Human infections of bird flu, or 'avian influenza,' are uncommon. When infections do occur, they usually result from close contact with infected birds, often in highly contaminated areas like chicken farms or wet markets. Symptoms of bird flu in humans can vary widely, including fever, eye irritation, upper respiratory issues like sore throat and cough, as well as headaches, muscle aches, and, in some cases, seizures. Symptoms typically appear around three to five days after the initial infection. Although such an outcome is very rare, bird flu can sometimes be fatal in humans should it lead to pneumonia, severe respiratory distress, or organ failure. It is difficult to ascertain when or if a bird flu would lead to an actual pandemic within the human population. Scientists can only keep track of the disease and research how it spreads and progresses over time.

(17). Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently; and because of the prevalence of mutations, two different types of the virus may be present in the same host cell and recombine, forming a dramatically different strain. The challenge is and has been for some time, the development of a productive vaccine.

question.text: Which of the following describes a way in which viruses can stay ahead of the “evolutionary arms race”?

options.label: A.
options.text: Viruses can lie and wait for years outside of a host

options.label: B.
options.text: Viruses can quickly multiply within a short period of time

options.label: C.
options.text: Viruses cause the immune system to be triggered during an infection

options.label: D.
options.text: Viruses can remain dormant within a host for years

options.label: E.
options.text: Viruses adapt to environmental changes by relying on host mechanisms

correct_answer_text: Viruses can quickly multiply within a short period of time

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, note that the phrase “evolutionary arms race” is referenced using quotation marks. This means that the phrase will be found directly in the passage. Indeed, paragraph 8 includes this phrase. It reads: “As part of the evolutionary arms race …a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies, and the virus is suddenly successful. It will again be able to quickly multiply while the host’s body is busy trying to recognize the new virus and create the appropriate antibodies.” This tells us that viruses can reproduce rapidly, which increases the likelihood that they will mutate and become unrecognizable to human immune systems, thus allowing them to stay ahead in the evolutionary arms race. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Viruses can lie and wait for years outside of a host – is incorrect because, while this may seem correct, a virus’s ability to lie and wait is not what makes it successful evolutionarily; it is what helps it to survive until it is ready to reproduce, as written in paragraph 2: “As  … viruses don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their own functions, they have the advantage of being able to lie dormant for years, waiting on a host cell to aid in their reproduction.” Option C. Viruses cause the immune system to be triggered during an infection – is incorrect because, based on the passage, triggering a host’s immune system is an unwanted outcome for a virus, since it increases the likelihood that the virus will be eliminated, thus making it unsuccessful evolutionarily. For example, when discussing bird flu in paragraph 14, the author states: “Had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by human immune systems.” Option D. Viruses can remain dormant within a host for years – is incorrect because, while this may seem correct, a virus’s ability to lay dormant and wait is not what makes it successful evolutionarily; it is only what helps it survive until it is ready to reproduce, as stated in paragraph 2: “Because they don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their functions, they also have the advantage of laying dormant for years as they wait for a host cell to aid them in reproduction.” Option E. Viruses adapt to environmental changes by relying on host mechanisms – is incorrect because, while this may seem correct, the author states in paragraph 8: “When a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies, and the virus is suddenly successful. It will again be able to quickly multiply while the host’s body is busy trying to recognize the new virus and create the appropriate antibodies.” This does not mention that viruses directly use host mechanisms to adapt to the environment; thus, this cannot be what helps them evolutionarily.

question.text: What is one way in which the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins mutate?

options.label: A.
options.text: They can mutate through antigenic drift

options.label: B.
options.text: They can mutate by producing pyrogens

options.label: C.
options.text: They can use their host’s cell to create offspring

options.label: D.
options.text: They use the lytic cycle to mutate

correct_answer_text: They can mutate through antigenic drift

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should search the passage for the paragraph or paragraphs discussing virus mutations. Mutations are discussed most in-depth in paragraphs 12–14, with paragraphs 12 and 13 discussing how hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins mutate: “There are two ways in which hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins can mutate. The first is by antigenic drift, which refers to mutations in the genetic code as a virus reproduces within… The second way the proteins can mutate is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus…” This tells us that one way that hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins mutate is through antigenic drift and antigenic shift, but the only answer choice available in the options is antigenic drift. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. They can mutate by producing pyrogens – is incorrect because paragraph 4 states that pyrogens are part of the body’s defense against viruses: “As the virions multiply and spread, the body’s immune response is often triggered and produces pyrogens. This response causes the body’s temperature to rise to induce a fever, which, in turn, causes metabolic processes in the body to slow down.” Option C. They can use their host’s cell to create offspring – is incorrect because paragraph 4 describes how hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins mutate; using a host cell to create offspring is not mentioned: “There are two ways in which hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins can mutate. The first is by antigenic drift, which refers to mutations in the genetic code as a virus reproduces within … The second way the proteins can mutate is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus…” Option D. They use the lytic cycle to mutate – is incorrect because paragraph 3 states that the lytic cycle is part of how viruses reproduce, not how hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins mutate: “There are two means by which a virus can reproduce. The first, employed by the common cold and flu viruses, is called the lytic cycle.”

Had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by human immune systems. However, this strain did not spread easily among humans and thus, did not turn into a pandemic.

(16). Human infections of bird flu, or 'avian influenza,' are uncommon. When infections do occur, they usually result from close contact with infected birds, often in highly contaminated areas like chicken farms or wet markets. Symptoms of bird flu in humans can vary widely, including fever, eye irritation, upper respiratory issues like sore throat and cough, as well as headaches, muscle aches, and, in some cases, seizures. Symptoms typically appear around three to five days after the initial infection. Although such an outcome is very rare, bird flu can sometimes be fatal in humans should it lead to pneumonia, severe respiratory distress, or organ failure. It is difficult to ascertain when or if a bird flu would lead to an actual pandemic within the human population. Scientists can only keep track of the disease and research how it spreads and progresses over time.

(17). Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently; and because of the prevalence of mutations, two different types of the virus may be present in the same host cell and recombine, forming a dramatically different strain. The challenge is and has been for some time, the development of a productive vaccine.

question.text: What is the primary reason why scientists encounter challenges when creating effective influenza vaccines?

options.label: A.
options.text: It is difficult for scientists to obtain influenza vaccine test subjects

options.label: B.
options.text: Antigenic mutations can be unpredictable

options.label: C.
options.text: Influenza viruses are difficult to isolate

options.label: D.
options.text: The Influenza virus can jump between species unexpectedly

options.label: E.
options.text: The influenza virus has the capacity to spread quickly

correct_answer_text: Antigenic mutations can be unpredictable

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage discussing vaccines. Vaccines are discussed in paragraphs 10, 11, and 12, and again briefly in paragraph 15; from here, we should scan each of these passages for the one which discusses the influenza vaccine. This is paragraph 12: “There are two ways in which hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins can mutate. The first is by antigenic drift, which refers to mutations in the genetic code as a virus reproduces within a cell. The genetic code of an ancestral virus drifts as it accumulates mutations in its proteins; when scientists develop flu shots, they are trying to predict what the accumulation of mutations will be in the coming flu season to develop an effective vaccine. Sometimes scientists can predict this with accuracy, and other times they may miss altogether.” This tells us that predicting the genetic code of an ancestral virus is difficult due to antigenic drift; thus, antigenic mutations can be unpredictable, and therefore scientists have a challenging time developing influenza vaccines. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. It is difficult for scientists to obtain vaccine test subjects – is incorrect because the passage does not mention the challenge of obtaining test subjects for the influenza vaccine. Option C. Influenza viruses are difficult to isolate – is incorrect because the passage does not mention influenza viruses being difficult to isolate. Option D. The Influenza virus can jump between species unexpectedly – is incorrect because this is true of influenza A mentioned in paragraph 14, but not all flu viruses. Additionally, paragraph 12 does not cite it as being a reason that vaccine production is challenging. Option E. The influenza virus has the capacity to spread quickly – is incorrect because, while this is true of viruses in general, the author states in paragraph 12, “If viruses are to successfully multiply and spread to new hosts, they must carry genes that allow this to happen.” Scientists’ ability to manufacture vaccines is not mentioned; thus, this is incorrect.

passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). Approximately 40 to 50 million people died during the Spanish Flu pandemic of 1918, all due to a parasite that is one-millionth of an inch long. As a ubiquitous part of our environment, this organism can only be seen with the aid of an electron microscope, yet it can wreak havoc on the cells of all living organisms. This parasite is called a virus.

(2). A virion is a virus particle that consists of genetic instructions wrapped in a coat of protein. Their genes consist of either DNA or RNA that is protected by a coat of protein. This coat protects their genetic information and aids in detecting the appropriate host cells to invade. Some viruses are surrounded by a lipid membrane, and some are not. The former is called an enveloped virus, and the latter is called a naked virus. These parasites do not have enzymes to carry out their chemical reactions and are entirely dependent on a host to make copies of themselves. Hosts include plants, bacteria, archaea, and animals. Because they don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their functions, they also have the advantage of laying dormant for years as they wait for a host cell to aid them in reproduction.

(3). There are two ways for a virus to reproduce. The first one, used by the common cold and flu viruses, is called the lytic cycle. As soon as the virus enters the host organism, the protein on the virus coat detects the appropriate host cell to invade. It then inserts itself into the wall of the host cell and releases its genetic material inside. This injected genetic material then utilizes the host’s metabolic processes and recruits the enzymes of the host cell to begin making new DNA or RNA strands along with new proteins for the outer wall. As soon as this is complete, the new particles assemble. They then break free either by lysis, which refers to the destruction of the cell or by budding, in which the new virions pinch out of the cell membrane and then carry a piece of the existing membrane with them. Now that there are more virions, they can spread and continue through a new lytic cycle.\

(4). As the virions multiply and spread, the body’s immune response is often triggered and produces pyrogens. This response causes the body’s temperature to rise to induce a fever, which, in turn, causes metabolic processes in the body to slow down. Normally the human body functions most efficiently at 37°C. A higher temperature causes the processes to slow down, slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells.

(5). The other cycle of multiplication is called the lysogenic cycle. This cycle is utilized by viruses that cause herpes and HIV. At the beginning of this cycle, the viruses invade the host’s cells, but they do not multiply. Instead, they mix their genes with the genes of the host so that when the host cell reproduces, the virus’s genetics are copied into the host cell’s offspring. They then often lie dormant until some environmental or genetic event triggers them, causing them to enter the lytic cycle and spread. Therefore, patients with HIV tend not to show symptoms of illness for years after contracting the virus, although the host is still contagious during this time. Perhaps the most infamous exemplification of this process occurred when Magic Johnson, a global icon at the time, announced his HIV-positive status in 1991. The news shocked the sports world and brought powerful awareness overnight.

(6). Johnson’s choice to go public with his HIV diagnosis was impactful for numerous reasons. In 1991, when Johnson made his announcement, those with HIV were often at the center of condemnation. It was a disease that much of the public believed was limited to marginalized communities and was also thought of as leading to a certain death since there existed no cure for the illness at the time. Johnson, being a high-profile celebrity and beloved sports figure, effectively challenged many people’s notions of HIV in terms of who it can impact. The athlete’s announcement humanized the disease in the eyes of many, leading to discussions surrounding prevention, testing, and treatment becoming much more commonplace. Johnson received significant praise for his decision to publicly announce his diagnosis and continues to advocate for reduced stigma of HIV, demonstrating that it is possible to live a full and healthy life as an HIV-positive individual.

(7). Viruses spread through many different means. They can use a carrier organism such as a mosquito or a fly to invade their next host, or they can travel through the air; or can transfer through direct contact of bodily fluids including blood, saliva, semen, vaginal fluid, sweat, or nasal discharge.

(8). Even though viruses cannot carry out their life cycle without a host, they are still susceptible to the same evolutionary pressures that affect other organisms precisely because they rely on other living organisms. If they are to successfully multiply and spread to new hosts, they must carry genes that allow this to happen. If they house genes that do not allow them to multiply effectively, perhaps killing the host within a few hours, those specific genes will disappear forever. On the other hand, if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.

(9). As part of the evolutionary arms race, host bodies busily create antibodies that can detect known viruses and lock them into their outer protein surface, thus preventing them from entering the host’s cells. When a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies, and the virus is suddenly successful. It will again be able to quickly multiply while the host’s body is busy trying to recognize the new virus and create the appropriate antibodies.

(10). Viruses can make millions of copies of themselves in seconds, which means that their mutation rate is much higher than in an organism that reproduces much more slowly. However, there is a difference in mutation rates between RNA virions and DNA virions. Viruses with DNA are more stable due to a proofreading check, which they have as part of their reproduction process. These virions use the host cell to check their DNA replication. If there is a mistake in the reproductive process, the host cell is often able to correct it. Therefore, viruses containing DNA do not mutate as frequently as RNA viruses. Two known RNA viruses include the influenza virus and the Human Immunodeficiency Virus, or HIV. As a result, these two viruses are of particular interest to scientists.

(11). When a person receives a vaccination, a small amount of virus is injected into their body, allowing the person’s immune system to create antibodies before they are exposed to the virus from the natural environment. Once they are exposed to the virus, the pre-existing antibodies will be able to quickly recognize and protect the person against the known virus before it can invade. However, RNA viruses such as the influenza virus, which causes the flu, have a high rate of mutation, which means that each year scientists must predict likely mutations in the flu virus to develop an effective vaccination.

(12). There are three types of influenza virus: A, B, and C. Type A influenza virus could infect an array of organisms including humans, pigs, dogs, horses, and birds. Along with the fact that it is an RNA virus, this wide range of hosts means that it has more possibility for mutations. Mutations in influenza virus A are limited to the virus’ surface proteins: hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. You may have heard of the H1N1 strain that caused a pandemic in 2009. The name H1N1 refers to mutations in these two proteins. In contrast, influenza virus types B and C are not able to infect other species, and therefore their mutation rate is much slower.

(13). There are two ways in which these proteins can mutate. The first is by antigenic drift, which refers to mutations in the genetic code as a virus reproduces within a cell. The genetic code of an ancestral virus drifts as it accumulates mutations in its proteins. When scientists develop flu shots, they aim to predict the accumulation of mutations in the coming flu season. Sometimes scientists can predict with some accuracy, and other times they may miss altogether.

(14). The second is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus. Because this strain is so dissimilar from either parent virus, it is difficult for the host’s immune system to detect. If this new virus is successful at reproducing and spreading, it could lead to a pandemic.

(15). Because influenza A can infect different species, it has more opportunities to mutate or recombine and create new strains of the virus. If the pig flu and the human flu enter the same host cell in a bird, they may recombine and create a dramatically different type of influenza strain. If this new strain mutates and spreads in a given organism, it has devastating potential. In 2003, the H5N1 strain, or bird flu, scared many people in that it was drastically different from previous strains. Had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by human immune systems. However, this strain did not spread easily among humans and thus, did not turn into a pandemic.

(16). Human infections of bird flu, or 'avian influenza,' are uncommon. When infections do occur, they usually result from close contact with infected birds, often in highly contaminated areas like chicken farms or wet markets. Symptoms of bird flu in humans can vary widely, including fever, eye irritation, upper respiratory issues like sore throat and cough, as well as headaches, muscle aches, and, in some cases, seizures. Symptoms typically appear around three to five days after the initial infection. Although such an outcome is very rare, bird flu can sometimes be fatal in humans should it lead to pneumonia, severe respiratory distress, or organ failure. It is difficult to ascertain when or if a bird flu would lead to an actual pandemic within the human population. Scientists can only keep track of the disease and research how it spreads and progresses over time.

(17). Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently; and because of the prevalence of mutations, two different types of the virus may be present in the same host cell and recombine, forming a dramatically different strain. The challenge is and has been for some time, the development of a productive vaccine.

question.text: At what temperature does the human body function most efficiently?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, it is helpful to consider that because the passage is related to viruses, a discussion relating to the temperature of the human body will probably be found in the section of the passage discussing the body’s response to viral invaders. Paragraph 11 covers this topic. It reads: “As the virions multiply and spread, the body’s immune response is often triggered and produces pyrogens; this causes the body’s temperature to rise, inducing a fever, which in turn causes metabolic processes in the body to slow down. Normally, a human body functions most efficiently at 37°C . A higher temperature causes the metabolic processes to slow down, in turn slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells.” This tells us that the human body functions best at 37°C. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 25°C – is incorrect because paragraph 11 specifies that the body functions best at 37, not 43°C: “Normally, a human body functions most efficiently at 37°C.” Option C. 38°C – is incorrect because paragraph 11 specifies that the body functions best at 37, not 25°C: “Normally, a human body functions most efficiently at 37°C.” Option D. 43°C – is incorrect because paragraph 11 specifies that the body functions best at 37, not 38°C: “Normally, a human body functions most efficiently at 37°C.”

question.text: Which of the following provides the most accurate description of antigenic shift?

options.label: A.
options.text: The formation of a new virus strain, acquired from two different virion types

options.label: B.
options.text: The mutations accumulated as a virus reproduces

options.label: C.
options.text: A slow shift in genes over time that leads to an epidemic

options.label: D.
options.text: The formation of a virus that can infect multiple species

options.label: E.
options.text: An accumulation of mutations over a short period of time

correct_answer_text: The formation of a new virus strain, acquired from two different virion types

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the term “antigenic shift” in the passage. It can be presumed that a description of antigenic shift will follow its initial, or only, mention in the text. Antigenic shift is referenced once in the passage, in paragraph 13: “The second way the proteins can mutate is by antigenic shift , which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus.” This tells us that antigenic shift is the formation of a new strain of virus, developed from two separate virion types. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. The mutations accumulated as a virus reproduces – is incorrect because an accumulation of mutations is related to antigenic drift, not shift. Option C. A slow shift in genes over time that leads to an epidemic – is incorrect because this is not mentioned in the passage. Neither antigenic drift nor shift involves a slow alteration in genes leading to an epidemic. Option D. The formation of a virus that can infect multiple species – is incorrect because, while this might seem correct when discussing antigenic shift, it is not the most accurate description of the phenomenon. It is the recombination of antigenic shift that allows it to be more infectious. Option E. An accumulation of mutations over a short period of time – is incorrect because an accumulation of mutations is related to antigenic drift, not shift.

Mutations in influenza virus A are limited to the virus’ surface proteins: hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. You may have heard of the H1N1 strain that caused a pandemic in 2009. The name H1N1 refers to mutations in these two proteins. In contrast, influenza virus types B and C are not able to infect other species, and therefore their mutation rate is much slower.

(13). There are two ways in which these proteins can mutate. The first is by antigenic drift, which refers to mutations in the genetic code as a virus reproduces within a cell. The genetic code of an ancestral virus drifts as it accumulates mutations in its proteins. When scientists develop flu shots, they aim to predict the accumulation of mutations in the coming flu season. Sometimes scientists can predict with some accuracy, and other times they may miss altogether.

(14). The second is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus. Because this strain is so dissimilar from either parent virus, it is difficult for the host’s immune system to detect. If this new virus is successful at reproducing and spreading, it could lead to a pandemic.

(15). Because influenza A can infect different species, it has more opportunities to mutate or recombine and create new strains of the virus. If the pig flu and the human flu enter the same host cell in a bird, they may recombine and create a dramatically different type of influenza strain. If this new strain mutates and spreads in a given organism, it has devastating potential. In 2003, the H5N1 strain, or bird flu, scared many people in that it was drastically different from previous strains. Had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by human immune systems. However, this strain did not spread easily among humans and thus, did not turn into a pandemic.

(16). Human infections of bird flu, or 'avian influenza,' are uncommon. When infections do occur, they usually result from close contact with infected birds, often in highly contaminated areas like chicken farms or wet markets. Symptoms of bird flu in humans can vary widely, including fever, eye irritation, upper respiratory issues like sore throat and cough, as well as headaches, muscle aches, and, in some cases, seizures. Symptoms typically appear around three to five days after the initial infection. Although such an outcome is very rare, bird flu can sometimes be fatal in humans should it lead to pneumonia, severe respiratory distress, or organ failure. It is difficult to ascertain when or if a bird flu would lead to an actual pandemic within the human population. Scientists can only keep track of the disease and research how it spreads and progresses over time.

(17). Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently; and because of the prevalence of mutations, two different types of the virus may be present in the same host cell and recombine, forming a dramatically different strain. The challenge is and has been for some time, the development of a productive vaccine.

question.text: Which pandemic resulted in the deaths of approximately 40 - 50 million individuals?

options.label: A.
options.text: H1N1

options.label: B.
options.text: HIV

options.label: C.
options.text: H5N1

options.label: D.
options.text: Spanish Flu

correct_answer_text: Spanish Flu

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should scan the passage for mention of the pandemics listed in the answer choices to ascertain the amount of people killed by each; by doing so, we can establish that the Spanish Flu is the only pandemic listed of which the passage includes a mortality rate. Paragraph 1 reads: “It is estimated that approximately 40 to 50 million people died during the Spanish Flu pandemic of 1918, all due to a parasite that is one-millionth of an inch long.” This tells us that the Spanish Flu was the pandemic that killed 40 – 50 million people. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. H1N1 – is incorrect because H1N1 is mentioned in paragraph 11 and its number of victims is not referenced: “You may have heard of the H1N1 strain that caused a pandemic in 2009; the name H1N1 refers to mutations in the hemagglutinin, and neuraminidase proteins.” Option B. HIV – is incorrect because, although HIV is mentioned at multiple intervals in the passage, its number of victims is not referenced. Option C. H5N1 – is incorrect because H5N1, or “bird flu” is mentioned in paragraph 14, but its fatality rate is not included: “In 2003, the H5N1 strain, or bird flu, scared many people because it was drastically different from previous strains; had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by the human immune system. However, this strain did not spread easily amongst humans; therefore, it did not turn into a pandemic.”

passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). Approximately 40 to 50 million people died during the Spanish Flu pandemic of 1918, all due to a parasite that is one-millionth of an inch long. As a ubiquitous part of our environment, this organism can only be seen with the aid of an electron microscope, yet it can wreak havoc on the cells of all living organisms. This parasite is called a virus.

(2). A virion is a virus particle that consists of genetic instructions wrapped in a coat of protein. Their genes consist of either DNA or RNA that is protected by a coat of protein. This coat protects their genetic information and aids in detecting the appropriate host cells to invade. Some viruses are surrounded by a lipid membrane, and some are not. The former is called an enveloped virus, and the latter is called a naked virus. These parasites do not have enzymes to carry out their chemical reactions and are entirely dependent on a host to make copies of themselves. Hosts include plants, bacteria, archaea, and animals. Because they don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their functions, they also have the advantage of laying dormant for years as they wait for a host cell to aid them in reproduction.

(3). There are two ways for a virus to reproduce. The first one, used by the common cold and flu viruses, is called the lytic cycle. As soon as the virus enters the host organism, the protein on the virus coat detects the appropriate host cell to invade. It then inserts itself into the wall of the host cell and releases its genetic material inside. This injected genetic material then utilizes the host’s metabolic processes and recruits the enzymes of the host cell to begin making new DNA or RNA strands along with new proteins for the outer wall. As soon as this is complete, the new particles assemble. They then break free either by lysis, which refers to the destruction of the cell or by budding, in which the new virions pinch out of the cell membrane and then carry a piece of the existing membrane with them. Now that there are more virions, they can spread and continue through a new lytic cycle.\

(4). As the virions multiply and spread, the body’s immune response is often triggered and produces pyrogens. This response causes the body’s temperature to rise to induce a fever, which, in turn, causes metabolic processes in the body to slow down. Normally the human body functions most efficiently at 37°C. A higher temperature causes the processes to slow down, slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells.

(5). The other cycle of multiplication is called the lysogenic cycle. This cycle is utilized by viruses that cause herpes and HIV. At the beginning of this cycle, the viruses invade the host’s cells, but they do not multiply. Instead, they mix their genes with the genes of the host so that when the host cell reproduces, the virus’s genetics are copied into the host cell’s offspring. They then often lie dormant until some environmental or genetic event triggers them, causing them to enter the lytic cycle and spread. Therefore, patients with HIV tend not to show symptoms of illness for years after contracting the virus, although the host is still contagious during this time. Perhaps the most infamous exemplification of this process occurred when Magic Johnson, a global icon at the time, announced his HIV-positive status in 1991. The news shocked the sports world and brought powerful awareness overnight.

(6). Johnson’s choice to go public with his HIV diagnosis was impactful for numerous reasons. In 1991, when Johnson made his announcement, those with HIV were often at the center of condemnation. It was a disease that much of the public believed was limited to marginalized communities and was also thought of as leading to a certain death since there existed no cure for the illness at the time. Johnson, being a high-profile celebrity and beloved sports figure, effectively challenged many people’s notions of HIV in terms of who it can impact. The athlete’s announcement humanized the disease in the eyes of many, leading to discussions surrounding prevention, testing, and treatment becoming much more commonplace. Johnson received significant praise for his decision to publicly announce his diagnosis and continues to advocate for reduced stigma of HIV, demonstrating that it is possible to live a full and healthy life as an HIV-positive individual.

(7). Viruses spread through many different means. They can use a carrier organism such as a mosquito or a fly to invade their next host, or they can travel through the air; or can transfer through direct contact of bodily fluids including blood, saliva, semen, vaginal fluid, sweat, or nasal discharge.

(8). Even though viruses cannot carry out their life cycle without a host, they are still susceptible to the same evolutionary pressures that affect other organisms precisely because they rely on other living organisms. If they are to successfully multiply and spread to new hosts, they must carry genes that allow this to happen. If they house genes that do not allow them to multiply effectively, perhaps killing the host within a few hours, those specific genes will disappear forever. On the other hand, if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.

(9). As part of the evolutionary arms race, host bodies busily create antibodies that can detect known viruses and lock them into their outer protein surface, thus preventing them from entering the host’s cells. When a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies, and the virus is suddenly successful. It will again be able to quickly multiply while the host’s body is busy trying to recognize the new virus and create the appropriate antibodies.

(10). Viruses can make millions of copies of themselves in seconds, which means that their mutation rate is much higher than in an organism that reproduces much more slowly. However, there is a difference in mutation rates between RNA virions and DNA virions. Viruses with DNA are more stable due to a proofreading check, which they have as part of their reproduction process. These virions use the host cell to check their DNA replication. If there is a mistake in the reproductive process, the host cell is often able to correct it. Therefore, viruses containing DNA do not mutate as frequently as RNA viruses. Two known RNA viruses include the influenza virus and the Human Immunodeficiency Virus, or HIV. As a result, these two viruses are of particular interest to scientists.

(11). When a person receives a vaccination, a small amount of virus is injected into their body, allowing the person’s immune system to create antibodies before they are exposed to the virus from the natural environment. Once they are exposed to the virus, the pre-existing antibodies will be able to quickly recognize and protect the person against the known virus before it can invade. However, RNA viruses such as the influenza virus, which causes the flu, have a high rate of mutation, which means that each year scientists must predict likely mutations in the flu virus to develop an effective vaccination.

(12). There are three types of influenza virus: A, B, and C. Type A influenza virus could infect an array of organisms including humans, pigs, dogs, horses, and birds. Along with the fact that it is an RNA virus, this wide range of hosts means that it has more possibility for mutations. Mutations in influenza virus A are limited to the virus’ surface proteins: hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. You may have heard of the H1N1 strain that caused a pandemic in 2009. The name H1N1 refers to mutations in these two proteins. In contrast, influenza virus types B and C are not able to infect other species, and therefore their mutation rate is much slower.

(13). There are two ways in which these proteins can mutate. The first is by antigenic drift, which refers to mutations in the genetic code as a virus reproduces within a cell. The genetic code of an ancestral virus drifts as it accumulates mutations in its proteins. When scientists develop flu shots, they aim to predict the accumulation of mutations in the coming flu season. Sometimes scientists can predict with some accuracy, and other times they may miss altogether.

(14). The second is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus. Because this strain is so dissimilar from either parent virus, it is difficult for the host’s immune system to detect. If this new virus is successful at reproducing and spreading, it could lead to a pandemic.

(15). Because influenza A can infect different species, it has more opportunities to mutate or recombine and create new strains of the virus. If the pig flu and the human flu enter the same host cell in a bird, they may recombine and create a dramatically different type of influenza strain. If this new strain mutates and spreads in a given organism, it has devastating potential. In 2003, the H5N1 strain, or bird flu, scared many people in that it was drastically different from previous strains. Had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by human immune systems. However, this strain did not spread easily among humans and thus, did not turn into a pandemic.

(16). Human infections of bird flu, or 'avian influenza,' are uncommon. When infections do occur, they usually result from close contact with infected birds, often in highly contaminated areas like chicken farms or wet markets. Symptoms of bird flu in humans can vary widely, including fever, eye irritation, upper respiratory issues like sore throat and cough, as well as headaches, muscle aches, and, in some cases, seizures. Symptoms typically appear around three to five days after the initial infection. Although such an outcome is very rare, bird flu can sometimes be fatal in humans should it lead to pneumonia, severe respiratory distress, or organ failure. It is difficult to ascertain when or if a bird flu would lead to an actual pandemic within the human population. Scientists can only keep track of the disease and research how it spreads and progresses over time.

(17). Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently; and because of the prevalence of mutations, two different types of the virus may be present in the same host cell and recombine, forming a dramatically different strain. The challenge is and has been for some time, the development of a productive vaccine.

question.text: A viral pandemic occurs because a virus has gone through a mutation that allows it to successfully spread.

options.label: A.
options.text: Both the statement and the reason are correct and related

options.label: B.
options.text: Both the statement and the reason are correct but NOT related

options.label: C.
options.text: The statement is correct but the reason is NOT

options.label: D.
options.text: The statement is NOT correct, but the reason is correct

options.label: E.
options.text: NEITHER the statement NOR the reason is correct

correct_answer_text: Both the statement and the reason are correct and related

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, note that both statements focus on a similar subtopic of the passage (the spreading of viruses). Thus, we should search the passage for paragraphs relating to this subject; this will allow us to locate the information necessary to ascertain the veracity and relatedness of both the statement and reason in the question stem. In paragraph 8, the author mentions the statement below. This tells us that mutations allow viruses to successfully spread. “When a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies and the virus is swiftly successful once more. It will again be able to quickly multiply, while the host’s body is busy attempting to recognize the newly mutated virus and create the appropriate antibodies.” In paragraph 13, the author mentions the statement below. This tells us that the spreading of mutated viruses can cause a pandemic. “Should this new virus be successful at reproducing and spreading, it can lead to a pandemic.” Altogether, paragraphs 8 and 13 tell us that pandemics can occur because of a mutation in a virus that has allowed it to successfully spread; hence, both the statement and reason in the question stem are correct and related. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Both the statement and the reason are correct but NOT related – is incorrect because the statement and reason are related. According to paragraphs 8 and 13, a mutation that allows a virus to successfully spread can cause a pandemic. Option C. The statement is correct, but the reason is NOT – is incorrect because the reason is correct. According to paragraphs 8 and 13, a mutation that allows for the successful spreading of a virus can cause a pandemic. Option D. The statement is NOT correct, but the reason is correct – is incorrect because the statement is also correct. According to paragraphs 8 and 13, a viral pandemic can occur, especially if a virus is successful at mutating. Option E. NEITHER the statement NOR the reason is correct – is incorrect because both the statement and the reason are correct. According to paragraphs 8 and 13, a mutation that allows for the successful spreading of a virus can cause a pandemic.

question.text: Why is influenza A particularly dangerous?

options.label: A.
options.text: It lies dormant within host cells

options.label: B.
options.text: It reproduces uncontrollably

options.label: C.
options.text: It can mutate and cause HIV

options.label: D.
options.text: It can infect different species

options.label: E.
options.text: It spreads more easily through populations

correct_answer_text: It can infect different species

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should first search the passage for the paragraph or paragraph discussing the different strains of influenza. Paragraph 11 discusses strains A, B, and C, but paragraph 14 provides the most details on influenza A. Its opening sentence reads: “As influenza A has the capacity to infect different species, it has more opportunity to mutate or recombine and create new strains of the virus…if this new strain mutates and spreads in an organism, it has devastating potential. In 2003, the H5N1 strain, or bird flu, scared many people because it was drastically different from previous strains; had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by the human immune system.” This tells us that influenza A is dangerous because it can infect multiple species, therefore having the opportunity to mutate and create new viral strains. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. It lies dormant within host cells – is incorrect because, while this is an advantage of the lysogenic cycle, it is not cited as a reason that influenza A is so dangerous. Option B. It reproduces uncontrollably – is incorrect because this is not cited in paragraph 14 as a reason that influenza A is so dangerous. Paragraph 14 states that influenza A can infect different species, not that it reproduces quickly. Option C. It can mutate and cause HIV – is incorrect because nowhere in the passage is it mentioned that HIV and influenza are related or that influenza can mutate, causing HIV. Option E. It spreads more easily through populations – is incorrect because, while the author states in paragraph 11, “type A influenza virus can infect an array of organisms including humans, pigs, dogs, horses, and birds. This, along with the fact that it is an RNA virus, means that it has more possibility for mutations,” this is not the same as stating that it is easily spread; thus, it is incorrect.

(8). Even though viruses cannot carry out their life cycle without a host, they are still susceptible to the same evolutionary pressures that affect other organisms precisely because they rely on other living organisms. If they are to successfully multiply and spread to new hosts, they must carry genes that allow this to happen. If they house genes that do not allow them to multiply effectively, perhaps killing the host within a few hours, those specific genes will disappear forever. On the other hand, if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.

(9). As part of the evolutionary arms race, host bodies busily create antibodies that can detect known viruses and lock them into their outer protein surface, thus preventing them from entering the host’s cells. When a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies, and the virus is suddenly successful. It will again be able to quickly multiply while the host’s body is busy trying to recognize the new virus and create the appropriate antibodies.

(10). Viruses can make millions of copies of themselves in seconds, which means that their mutation rate is much higher than in an organism that reproduces much more slowly. However, there is a difference in mutation rates between RNA virions and DNA virions. Viruses with DNA are more stable due to a proofreading check, which they have as part of their reproduction process. These virions use the host cell to check their DNA replication. If there is a mistake in the reproductive process, the host cell is often able to correct it. Therefore, viruses containing DNA do not mutate as frequently as RNA viruses. Two known RNA viruses include the influenza virus and the Human Immunodeficiency Virus, or HIV. As a result, these two viruses are of particular interest to scientists.

(11). When a person receives a vaccination, a small amount of virus is injected into their body, allowing the person’s immune system to create antibodies before they are exposed to the virus from the natural environment. Once they are exposed to the virus, the pre-existing antibodies will be able to quickly recognize and protect the person against the known virus before it can invade. However, RNA viruses such as the influenza virus, which causes the flu, have a high rate of mutation, which means that each year scientists must predict likely mutations in the flu virus to develop an effective vaccination.

(12). There are three types of influenza virus: A, B, and C. Type A influenza virus could infect an array of organisms including humans, pigs, dogs, horses, and birds. Along with the fact that it is an RNA virus, this wide range of hosts means that it has more possibility for mutations. Mutations in influenza virus A are limited to the virus’ surface proteins: hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. You may have heard of the H1N1 strain that caused a pandemic in 2009. The name H1N1 refers to mutations in these two proteins. In contrast, influenza virus types B and C are not able to infect other species, and therefore their mutation rate is much slower.

(13). There are two ways in which these proteins can mutate. The first is by antigenic drift, which refers to mutations in the genetic code as a virus reproduces within a cell. The genetic code of an ancestral virus drifts as it accumulates mutations in its proteins. When scientists develop flu shots, they aim to predict the accumulation of mutations in the coming flu season. Sometimes scientists can predict with some accuracy, and other times they may miss altogether.

(14). The second is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus. Because this strain is so dissimilar from either parent virus, it is difficult for the host’s immune system to detect. If this new virus is successful at reproducing and spreading, it could lead to a pandemic.

(15). Because influenza A can infect different species, it has more opportunities to mutate or recombine and create new strains of the virus. If the pig flu and the human flu enter the same host cell in a bird, they may recombine and create a dramatically different type of influenza strain. If this new strain mutates and spreads in a given organism, it has devastating potential. In 2003, the H5N1 strain, or bird flu, scared many people in that it was drastically different from previous strains. Had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by human immune systems. However, this strain did not spread easily among humans and thus, did not turn into a pandemic.

(16). Human infections of bird flu, or 'avian influenza,' are uncommon. When infections do occur, they usually result from close contact with infected birds, often in highly contaminated areas like chicken farms or wet markets. Symptoms of bird flu in humans can vary widely, including fever, eye irritation, upper respiratory issues like sore throat and cough, as well as headaches, muscle aches, and, in some cases, seizures. Symptoms typically appear around three to five days after the initial infection. Although such an outcome is very rare, bird flu can sometimes be fatal in humans should it lead to pneumonia, severe respiratory distress, or organ failure. It is difficult to ascertain when or if a bird flu would lead to an actual pandemic within the human population. Scientists can only keep track of the disease and research how it spreads and progresses over time.

(17). Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently; and because of the prevalence of mutations, two different types of the virus may be present in the same host cell and recombine, forming a dramatically different strain. The challenge is and has been for some time, the development of a productive vaccine.

question.text: What is the purpose of a fever in fighting an infection?

options.label: A.
options.text: It allows viruses to be expelled from the body through sweat pores

options.label: B.
options.text: It increases the metabolic processes to improve immune response

options.label: C.
options.text: It increases the body’s temperature to kill viral invaders

options.label: D.
options.text: It Increases the body's temperature so it can function more efficiently

options.label: E.
options.text: It slows down viral replication

correct_answer_text: It slows down viral replication

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, note that the information requested in the question stem applies to relatively basic information about viruses (how the human body reacts to them). Thus, we can presume that such information will be found early in the passage. Indeed, the body’s immune response to viruses is discussed in paragraph 4. It reads: “As the virions multiply and spread, the body’s immune response is often triggered and produces pyrogens; this causes the body’s temperature to rise, inducing a fever…a higher temperature causes the metabolic processes to slow down, in turn slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells.” This tells us that when a body’s temperature rises and triggers a fever, it leads to a slowing in the multiplication of virions. Therefore, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. It allows viruses to be expelled from the body through sweat pores – is incorrect because there is no mention of viruses being expelled from sweat pores in the passage. Option B. It increases the metabolic processes to improve immune response – is incorrect because in paragraph 4, it states: “A higher temperature causes the metabolic processes to slow down, in turn slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells.” Option C. It increases the body’s temperature to kill viral invaders – is incorrect because paragraph 4 states that the body’s temperature doesn’t directly kill a virus, only that “a higher temperature causes the metabolic processes to slow down, in turn slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells. “ Option D. It Increases the body’s temperature so it can function more efficiently – is incorrect because, in paragraph 4, the author states: “A higher temperature causes the metabolic processes to slow down, in turn slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells.” This does not indicate that a higher temperature helps the body to function more efficiently.

passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). Approximately 40 to 50 million people died during the Spanish Flu pandemic of 1918, all due to a parasite that is one-millionth of an inch long. As a ubiquitous part of our environment, this organism can only be seen with the aid of an electron microscope, yet it can wreak havoc on the cells of all living organisms. This parasite is called a virus.

(2). A virion is a virus particle that consists of genetic instructions wrapped in a coat of protein. Their genes consist of either DNA or RNA that is protected by a coat of protein. This coat protects their genetic information and aids in detecting the appropriate host cells to invade. Some viruses are surrounded by a lipid membrane, and some are not. The former is called an enveloped virus, and the latter is called a naked virus. These parasites do not have enzymes to carry out their chemical reactions and are entirely dependent on a host to make copies of themselves. Hosts include plants, bacteria, archaea, and animals. Because they don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their functions, they also have the advantage of laying dormant for years as they wait for a host cell to aid them in reproduction.

(3). There are two ways for a virus to reproduce. The first one, used by the common cold and flu viruses, is called the lytic cycle. As soon as the virus enters the host organism, the protein on the virus coat detects the appropriate host cell to invade. It then inserts itself into the wall of the host cell and releases its genetic material inside. This injected genetic material then utilizes the host’s metabolic processes and recruits the enzymes of the host cell to begin making new DNA or RNA strands along with new proteins for the outer wall. As soon as this is complete, the new particles assemble. They then break free either by lysis, which refers to the destruction of the cell or by budding, in which the new virions pinch out of the cell membrane and then carry a piece of the existing membrane with them. Now that there are more virions, they can spread and continue through a new lytic cycle.\

(4). As the virions multiply and spread, the body’s immune response is often triggered and produces pyrogens. This response causes the body’s temperature to rise to induce a fever, which, in turn, causes metabolic processes in the body to slow down. Normally the human body functions most efficiently at 37°C. A higher temperature causes the processes to slow down, slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells.

(5). The other cycle of multiplication is called the lysogenic cycle. This cycle is utilized by viruses that cause herpes and HIV. At the beginning of this cycle, the viruses invade the host’s cells, but they do not multiply. Instead, they mix their genes with the genes of the host so that when the host cell reproduces, the virus’s genetics are copied into the host cell’s offspring. They then often lie dormant until some environmental or genetic event triggers them, causing them to enter the lytic cycle and spread. Therefore, patients with HIV tend not to show symptoms of illness for years after contracting the virus, although the host is still contagious during this time. Perhaps the most infamous exemplification of this process occurred when Magic Johnson, a global icon at the time, announced his HIV-positive status in 1991. The news shocked the sports world and brought powerful awareness overnight.

(6). Johnson’s choice to go public with his HIV diagnosis was impactful for numerous reasons. In 1991, when Johnson made his announcement, those with HIV were often at the center of condemnation. It was a disease that much of the public believed was limited to marginalized communities and was also thought of as leading to a certain death since there existed no cure for the illness at the time. Johnson, being a high-profile celebrity and beloved sports figure, effectively challenged many people’s notions of HIV in terms of who it can impact. The athlete’s announcement humanized the disease in the eyes of many, leading to discussions surrounding prevention, testing, and treatment becoming much more commonplace. Johnson received significant praise for his decision to publicly announce his diagnosis and continues to advocate for reduced stigma of HIV, demonstrating that it is possible to live a full and healthy life as an HIV-positive individual.

(7). Viruses spread through many different means. They can use a carrier organism such as a mosquito or a fly to invade their next host, or they can travel through the air; or can transfer through direct contact of bodily fluids including blood, saliva, semen, vaginal fluid, sweat, or nasal discharge.

(8). Even though viruses cannot carry out their life cycle without a host, they are still susceptible to the same evolutionary pressures that affect other organisms precisely because they rely on other living organisms. If they are to successfully multiply and spread to new hosts, they must carry genes that allow this to happen. If they house genes that do not allow them to multiply effectively, perhaps killing the host within a few hours, those specific genes will disappear forever. On the other hand, if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.

(9). As part of the evolutionary arms race, host bodies busily create antibodies that can detect known viruses and lock them into their outer protein surface, thus preventing them from entering the host’s cells. When a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies, and the virus is suddenly successful. It will again be able to quickly multiply while the host’s body is busy trying to recognize the new virus and create the appropriate antibodies.

(10). Viruses can make millions of copies of themselves in seconds, which means that their mutation rate is much higher than in an organism that reproduces much more slowly. However, there is a difference in mutation rates between RNA virions and DNA virions. Viruses with DNA are more stable due to a proofreading check, which they have as part of their reproduction process. These virions use the host cell to check their DNA replication. If there is a mistake in the reproductive process, the host cell is often able to correct it. Therefore, viruses containing DNA do not mutate as frequently as RNA viruses. Two known RNA viruses include the influenza virus and the Human Immunodeficiency Virus, or HIV. As a result, these two viruses are of particular interest to scientists.

(11). When a person receives a vaccination, a small amount of virus is injected into their body, allowing the person’s immune system to create antibodies before they are exposed to the virus from the natural environment. Once they are exposed to the virus, the pre-existing antibodies will be able to quickly recognize and protect the person against the known virus before it can invade. However, RNA viruses such as the influenza virus, which causes the flu, have a high rate of mutation, which means that each year scientists must predict likely mutations in the flu virus to develop an effective vaccination.

(12). There are three types of influenza virus: A, B, and C. Type A influenza virus could infect an array of organisms including humans, pigs, dogs, horses, and birds. Along with the fact that it is an RNA virus, this wide range of hosts means that it has more possibility for mutations. Mutations in influenza virus A are limited to the virus’ surface proteins: hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. You may have heard of the H1N1 strain that caused a pandemic in 2009. The genetic code of an ancestral virus drifts as it accumulates mutations in its proteins. Sometimes scientists can predict with some accuracy, and other times they may miss altogether.

(14). The second is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus. Because this strain is so dissimilar from either parent virus, it is difficult for the host’s immune system to detect. If this new virus is successful at reproducing and spreading, it could lead to a pandemic.

question.text: Each of the following are cited in the passage as bodily fluids through which viruses can travel EXCEPT one. Which is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: Blood

options.label: B.
options.text: Saliva

options.label: C.
options.text: Tears

options.label: D.
options.text: Nasal discharge

correct_answer_text: Tears

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage discussing how viruses specifically spread through fluids. Paragraph 6 contains such information: “Viruses spread through many different means; they can use a carrier organism such as a mosquito or a fly to invade their next host, they can travel through air, or they can be transferred through direct contact of bodily fluids including blood , saliva , semen, vaginal fluid, sweat or nasal discharge .” The only option choice NOT listed here is tears . Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Blood – is incorrect because paragraph 6 lists blood as a fluid through which viruses can travel: “Viruses spread through many different means; they can use a carrier organism such as a mosquito or a fly to invade their next host, they can travel through air, or they can be transferred through direct contact of bodily fluids including blood, saliva, semen, vaginal fluid, sweat or nasal discharge.” Option B. Saliva – is incorrect because paragraph 6 lists saliva as a fluid through which viruses can travel: “Viruses spread through many different means; they can use a carrier organism such as a mosquito or a fly to invade their next host, they can travel through air, or they can be transferred through direct contact of bodily fluids including blood, saliva, semen, vaginal fluid, sweat or nasal discharge.” Option D. Nasal discharge – is incorrect because paragraph 6 lists nasal discharge as a fluid through which viruses can travel: “Viruses spread through many different means; they can use a carrier organism such as a mosquito or a fly to invade their next host, they can travel through air, or they can be transferred through direct contact of bodily fluids including blood, saliva, semen, vaginal fluid, sweat or nasal discharge.”
