question.text: With which of the following statements would the author most likely agree?

options.label: A.
options.text: RNA viruses are much more dangerous than DNA viruses

options.label: B.
options.text: HIV is the most lethal and infectious viral disease known today

options.label: C.
options.text: Antibodies of viruses alert the immune system to produce complementary antibodies

options.label: D.
options.text: Healthcare professionals must focus on treatment rather than prevention

correct_answer_text: RNA viruses are much more dangerous than DNA viruses

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we need to ascertain which of the above statements are supported in the passage; this can be accomplished using the process of elimination. HIV is mentioned in paragraphs 5, 10, and 17. Although these paragraphs tell us that the author would agree that HIV is highly problematic, we cannot assume that the author believes it to be the most infectious viral disease known today. “…patients with HIV tend not to show symptoms of illness for years after contracting the virus, although the host is still contagious during this time…Two known RNA viruses include the influenza virus and the Human Immunodeficiency Virus, or HIV. As a result, these two viruses are of particular interest to scientists . …Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently.” Antibodies are mentioned in paragraphs 9 and 11. These paragraphs do not tell us that antibodies of viruses alert the human immune system to produce complementary antibodies; therefore, it cannot be said that the author of the passage agrees with such a statement. “When a person receives a vaccination, a small amount of virus is injected into their body, allowing the person’s immune system to create antibodies…Once they are exposed to the virus, the pre-existing antibodies will be able to quickly recognize and protect the person…As part of the evolutionary arms race, host bodies busily create antibodies that can detect known viruses…when a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies, and the virus is suddenly successful. It will again be able to quickly multiply while the host’s body is busy trying to recognize the new virus and create the appropriate antibodies.” Regarding the fourth option choice, treatment and prevention are not mentioned in the passage. As we have established that the second, third and fourth answer choices are incorrect, the fifth answer choice can automatically be eliminated. This leaves only the first option choice “RNA viruses are much more dangerous than DNA viruses.” To further prove that the author would likely agree with this statement, paragraphs 10 and 11 read: “…viruses containing DNA do not mutate as frequently as RNA viruses...however, RNA viruses such as the influenza virus, which causes the flu, have a high rate of mutation, which means that each year scientists must predict likely mutations in the flu virus to develop an effective vaccination.” As these paragraphs state that RNA viruses mutate faster than DNA viruses and are thus more challenging to inoculate against than DNA viruses, this tells us that the author WOULD likely agree that RNA viruses are more dangerous than DNA viruses. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. HIV is the most lethal and infectious viral disease known today – is incorrect because, when discussing HIV in paragraphs 5, 10, and 17, the author does not suggest that HIV is the most lethal and infectious viral disease known today. Option C. Antibodies of viruses alert the immune system to produce complementary antibodies – is incorrect because, when discussing antibodies in paragraphs 9 and 11, the author does not mention that the antibodies of viruses alert the human immune system to produce complementary antibodies; thus, this is incorrect. Option D. Healthcare professionals must focus on treatment rather than prevention – is incorrect because the passage does not discuss treatment versus prevention; thus, we cannot assume that the author would agree or disagree with this statement.

As a ubiquitous part of our environment, this organism can only be seen with the aid of an electron microscope, yet it can wreak havoc on the cells of all living organisms. (2). A virion is a virus particle that consists of genetic instructions wrapped in a coat of protein. Their genes consist of either DNA or RNA that is protected by a coat of protein. This coat protects their genetic information and aids in detecting the appropriate host cells to invade. Some viruses are surrounded by a lipid membrane, and some are not. The former is called an enveloped virus, and the latter is called a naked virus. These parasites do not have enzymes to carry out their chemical reactions and are entirely dependent on a host to make copies of themselves. Hosts include plants, bacteria, archaea, and animals. Because they don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their functions, they also have the advantage of laying dormant for years as they wait for a host cell to aid them in reproduction.

(3). There are two ways for a virus to reproduce. The first one, used by the common cold and flu viruses, is called the lytic cycle. As soon as the virus enters the host organism, the protein on the virus coat detects the appropriate host cell to invade. It then inserts itself into the wall of the host cell and releases its genetic material inside. This injected genetic material then utilizes the host’s metabolic processes and recruits the enzymes of the host cell to begin making new DNA or RNA strands along with new proteins for the outer wall. As soon as this is complete, the new particles assemble. They then break free either by lysis, which refers to the destruction of the cell or by budding, in which the new virions pinch out of the cell membrane and then carry a piece of the existing membrane with them. Now that there are more virions, they can spread and continue through a new lytic cycle.\

(4). As the virions multiply and spread, the body’s immune response is often triggered and produces pyrogens. This response causes the body’s temperature to rise to induce a fever, which, in turn, causes metabolic processes in the body to slow down. Normally the human body functions most efficiently at 37°C. A higher temperature causes the processes to slow down, slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells.

(5). The other cycle of multiplication is called the lysogenic cycle. This cycle is utilized by viruses that cause herpes and HIV. At the beginning of this cycle, the viruses invade the host’s cells, but they do not multiply. Instead, they mix their genes with the genes of the host so that when the host cell reproduces, the virus’s genetics are copied into the host cell’s offspring. They then often lie dormant until some environmental or genetic event triggers them, causing them to enter the lytic cycle and spread. Therefore, patients with HIV tend not to show symptoms of illness for years after contracting the virus, although the host is still contagious during this time. Perhaps the most infamous exemplification of this process occurred when Magic Johnson, a global icon at the time, announced his HIV-positive status in 1991. The news shocked the sports world and brought powerful awareness overnight.

(6). Johnson’s choice to go public with his HIV diagnosis was impactful for numerous reasons. In 1991, when Johnson made his announcement, those with HIV were often at the center of condemnation. It was a disease that much of the public believed was limited to marginalized communities and was also thought of as leading to a certain death since there existed no cure for the illness at the time. Johnson, being a high-profile celebrity and beloved sports figure, effectively challenged many people’s notions of HIV in terms of who it can impact. The athlete’s announcement humanized the disease in the eyes of many, leading to discussions surrounding prevention, testing, and treatment becoming much more commonplace. Johnson received significant praise for his decision to publicly announce his diagnosis and continues to advocate for reduced stigma of HIV, demonstrating that it is possible to live a full and healthy life as an HIV-positive individual.

(7). Viruses spread through many different means. They can use a carrier organism such as a mosquito or a fly to invade their next host, or they can travel through the air; or can transfer through direct contact of bodily fluids including blood, saliva, semen, vaginal fluid, sweat, or nasal discharge.

(8). Even though viruses cannot carry out their life cycle without a host, they are still susceptible to the same evolutionary pressures that affect other organisms precisely because they rely on other living organisms. If they are to successfully multiply and spread to new hosts, they must carry genes that allow this to happen. If they house genes that do not allow them to multiply effectively, perhaps killing the host within a few hours, those specific genes will disappear forever. On the other hand, if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.

(9). As part of the evolutionary arms race, host bodies busily create antibodies that can detect known viruses and lock them into their outer protein surface, thus preventing them from entering the host’s cells. When a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies, and the virus is suddenly successful. It will again be able to quickly multiply while the host’s body is busy trying to recognize the new virus and create the appropriate antibodies.

(10). Viruses can make millions of copies of themselves in seconds, which means that their mutation rate is much higher than in an organism that reproduces much more slowly. However, there is a difference in mutation rates between RNA virions and DNA virions. Viruses with DNA are more stable due to a proofreading check, which they have as part of their reproduction process. These virions use the host cell to check their DNA replication. If there is a mistake in the reproductive process, the host cell is often able to correct it. Therefore, viruses containing DNA do not mutate as frequently as RNA viruses. Two known RNA viruses include the influenza virus and the Human Immunodeficiency Virus, or HIV. As a result, these two viruses are of particular interest to scientists.

(11). When a person receives a vaccination, a small amount of virus is injected into their body, allowing the person’s immune system to create antibodies before they are exposed to the virus from the natural environment. Once they are exposed to the virus, the pre-existing antibodies will be able to quickly recognize and protect the person against the known virus before it can invade. However, RNA viruses such as the influenza virus, which causes the flu, have a high rate of mutation, which means that each year scientists must predict likely mutations in the flu virus to develop an effective vaccination.

(12). There are three types of influenza virus: A, B, and C. Type A influenza virus could infect an array of organisms including humans, pigs, dogs, horses, and birds. Along with the fact that it is an RNA virus, this wide range of hosts means that it has more possibility for mutations. Mutations in influenza virus A are limited to the virus’ surface proteins: hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. You may have heard of the H1N1 strain that caused a pandemic in 2009. The name H1N1 refers to mutations in these two proteins. In contrast, influenza virus types B and C are not able to infect other species, and therefore their mutation rate is much slower.

(13). There are two ways in which these proteins can mutate. The first is by antigenic drift, which refers to mutations in the genetic code as a virus reproduces within a cell. The genetic code of an ancestral virus drifts as it accumulates mutations in its proteins. When scientists develop flu shots, they aim to predict the accumulation of mutations in the coming flu season. Sometimes scientists can predict with some accuracy, and other times they may miss altogether.

(14). The second is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus. Because this strain is so dissimilar from either parent virus, it is difficult for the host’s immune system to detect. If this new virus is successful at reproducing and spreading, it could lead to a pandemic.

(15). Because influenza A can infect different species, it has more opportunities to mutate or recombine and create new strains of the virus. If the pig flu and the human flu enter the same host cell in a bird, they may recombine and create a dramatically different type of influenza strain. If this new strain mutates and spreads in a given organism, it has devastating potential. In 2003, the H5N1 strain, or bird flu, scared many people in that it was drastically different from previous strains. Had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by human immune systems. However, this strain did not spread easily among humans and thus, did not turn into a pandemic.

(16). Human infections of bird flu, or 'avian influenza,' are uncommon. When infections do occur, they usually result from close contact with infected birds, often in highly contaminated areas like chicken farms or wet markets. Symptoms of bird flu in humans can vary widely, including fever, eye irritation, upper respiratory issues like sore throat and cough, as well as headaches, muscle aches, and, in some cases, seizures. Symptoms typically appear around three to five days after the initial infection. Although such an outcome is very rare, bird flu can sometimes be fatal in humans should it lead to pneumonia, severe respiratory distress, or organ failure. It is difficult to ascertain when or if a bird flu would lead to an actual pandemic within the human population. Scientists can only keep track of the disease and research how it spreads and progresses over time.

(17). Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently; and because of the prevalence of mutations, two different types of the virus may be present in the same host cell and recombine, forming a dramatically different strain. The challenge is and has been for some time, the development of a productive vaccine.

question.text: What was the aim of referencing Magic as an HIV victim in paragraph five?

options.label: A.
options.text: Magic was mentioned to exemplify the dormant nature of HIV

options.label: B.
options.text: He was mentioned as a means of humanizing HIV

options.label: C.
options.text: He was mentioned to show that HIV does not discriminate between health, race, or standing

options.label: D.
options.text: He was mentioned to show that HIV can remain dormant for more than 10 years

options.label: E.
options.text: The mention of Magic made no contribution to the passage

correct_answer_text: Magic was mentioned to exemplify the dormant nature of HIV

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should first carefully read the section of paragraph 5 mentioning Magic. The paragraph uses Magic Johnson as an example of a patient with HIV who did not show symptoms for many years. It reads: “Therefore, patients with HIV tend not to show symptoms of illness for years after contracting the virus, although the host patient is still contagious during this time. Perhaps the most infamous exemplification of this process occurred when Magic Johnson, a global icon at the time, announced his HIV-positive status in 1991. The news about Johnson shocked the sports world and brought powerful awareness about HIV to light overnight.” Thus, Magic was mentioned as a means of underscoring the dormant nature of HIV. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. He was mentioned as a means of humanizing HIV – is incorrect because, while providing an example of a well-known figure with HIV makes the disease seem more real, this is not the best way to describe the impact of mentioning Magic in the passage. The purpose of mentioning Magic is to provide an example of how HIV can remain dormant for many years. Option C. He was mentioned to show that HIV does not discriminate between health, race, or standing – is incorrect because, while providing an example of a well-known figure makes HIV appear less discriminatory, this is not the best way to describe the impact of mentioning Magic in the passage. Mentioning Magic provides an example of how HIV can remain dormant for many years. Option D. He was mentioned to show HIV can remain dormant for more than 10 years – is incorrect because, while this is almost correct, there is no mention of how HIV can remain dormant for only 10 years. Option E. The mention of Magic made no contribution to the passage – is incorrect because mentioning Magic does serve a purpose – it tells the reader that HIV can remain dormant for many years.

question.text: Which of the following viruses would be regarded as most successful?

options.label: A.
options.text: A virus that kills its host within 24 hours

options.label: B.
options.text: A virus that infects a host for 6 days and is spread to 8 more hosts

options.label: C.
options.text: A virus that infects a host for 7 days and is spread to 10 more hosts

options.label: D.
options.text: A virus that infects a host for 14 days and is spread to 4 more hosts

options.label: E.
options.text: A virus that kills its host after 20 days and is spread to 9 more hosts

correct_answer_text: A virus that infects a host for 7 days and is spread to 10 more hosts

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage discussing the lifecycle of viruses; information regarding the lifecycle of viruses can be found in paragraph 8. This tells us that the virus which is most successful is one that can keep its host alive, thus spreading across a wider population. Therefore, the correct answer will be that which describes a virus that spreads to most people. It reads: “If they are to successfully multiply and spread to new hosts, they must carry genes that allow this to happen. If they house genes that do not allow them to multiply effectively, perhaps killing the host within a few hours, those specific genes will disappear forever. On the other hand, if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.” The third option in the answer choices describes a virus that both keeps its host alive and spreads to ten other hosts, the greatest number of hosts mentioned in the answer choices. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. A virus that kills its host within 24 hours – is incorrect because, while this would certainly be deadly towards its host, it would not be considered a successful virus, as its successful genes cannot be passed on. Option B. A virus that infects a host for 6 days and is spread to 8 more hosts – is incorrect because while this virus has a long-lasting infection, it only spreads to 8 hosts. According to paragraph 8, “if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.” Since this option choice does not describe a virus that spreads to the greatest number of hosts, the virus described here is not the most successful. Option D. A virus that infects a host for 14 days and is spread to 4 more hosts – is incorrect because, while this virus has a long-lasting infection, it only spreads to 4 hosts. According to paragraph 8, “if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.” Since this option choice does not describe a virus that spreads to the greatest number of hosts, the virus described here is not the most successful. Option E. A virus that kills its host after 20 days and is spread to 9 more hosts – is incorrect because, while this virus has a long-lasting infection, it only spreads to 9 hosts. According to paragraph 8, “if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.” Since this option choice does not describe a virus that spreads to the greatest number of hosts, the virus described here is not the most successful.

Symptoms of bird flu in humans can vary widely, including fever, eye irritation, upper respiratory issues like sore throat and cough, as well as headaches, muscle aches, and, in some cases, seizures. Symptoms typically appear around three to five days after the initial infection. Although such an outcome is very rare, bird flu can sometimes be fatal in humans should it lead to pneumonia, severe respiratory distress, or organ failure. It is difficult to ascertain when or if a bird flu would lead to an actual pandemic within the human population. Scientists can only keep track of the disease and research how it spreads and progresses over time.

(17). Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently; and because of the prevalence of mutations, two different types of the virus may be present in the same host cell and recombine, forming a dramatically different strain. The challenge is and has been for some time, the development of a productive vaccine.

question.text: Which of the following viruses contain RNA genes?

options.label: A.
options.text: Epstein–Barr virus

options.label: B.
options.text: Human Immunodeficiency Virus

options.label: C.
options.text: Herpes simplex virus

options.label: D.
options.text: Poxviruses

options.label: E.
options.text: Adenoviruses

correct_answer_text: Human Immunodeficiency Virus

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the portion of the passage with the most in-depth discussion of RNA viruses. RNA viruses are described most thoroughly in paragraph 10; its final two sentences read: “Two known RNA viruses include the influenza virus and the Human Immunodeficiency Virus, or HIV . As a result, these two viruses are of particular interest to scientists.” This tells us that HIV is an RNA virus. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Epstein–Barr virus – is incorrect because this virus is not mentioned in the passage. Option C. Herpes simplex virus – is incorrect because, while both HIV and herpes utilize the lysogenic cycle, herpes is not mentioned to be an RNA gene-containing virus. Option D. Poxviruses – is incorrect because these viruses are not mentioned in the passage. Option E. Adenoviruses – is incorrect because these viruses are not mentioned in the passage.

passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). Approximately 40 to 50 million people died during the Spanish Flu pandemic of 1918, all due to a parasite that is one-millionth of an inch long. As a ubiquitous part of our environment, this organism can only be seen with the aid of an electron microscope, yet it can wreak havoc on the cells of all living organisms. This parasite is called a virus.

(2). A virion is a virus particle that consists of genetic instructions wrapped in a coat of protein. Their genes consist of either DNA or RNA that is protected by a coat of protein. This coat protects their genetic information and aids in detecting the appropriate host cells to invade. Some viruses are surrounded by a lipid membrane, and some are not. The former is called an enveloped virus, and the latter is called a naked virus. These parasites do not have enzymes to carry out their chemical reactions and are entirely dependent on a host to make copies of themselves. Hosts include plants, bacteria, archaea, and animals. Because they don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their functions, they also have the advantage of laying dormant for years as they wait for a host cell to aid them in reproduction.

(3). There are two ways for a virus to reproduce. The first one, used by the common cold and flu viruses, is called the lytic cycle. As soon as the virus enters the host organism, the protein on the virus coat detects the appropriate host cell to invade. It then inserts itself into the wall of the host cell and releases its genetic material inside. This injected genetic material then utilizes the host’s metabolic processes and recruits the enzymes of the host cell to begin making new DNA or RNA strands along with new proteins for the outer wall. As soon as this is complete, the new particles assemble. They then break free either by lysis, which refers to the destruction of the cell or by budding, in which the new virions pinch out of the cell membrane and then carry a piece of the existing membrane with them. Now that there are more virions, they can spread and continue through a new lytic cycle.\

(4). As the virions multiply and spread, the body’s immune response is often triggered and produces pyrogens. This response causes the body’s temperature to rise to induce a fever, which, in turn, causes metabolic processes in the body to slow down. Normally the human body functions most efficiently at 37°C. A higher temperature causes the processes to slow down, slowing the metabolism of the host cells and the multiplication of the virions within the host cells.

(5). The other cycle of multiplication is called the lysogenic cycle. This cycle is utilized by viruses that cause herpes and HIV. At the beginning of this cycle, the viruses invade the host’s cells, but they do not multiply. Instead, they mix their genes with the genes of the host so that when the host cell reproduces, the virus’s genetics are copied into the host cell’s offspring. They then often lie dormant until some environmental or genetic event triggers them, causing them to enter the lytic cycle and spread. Therefore, patients with HIV tend not to show symptoms of illness for years after contracting the virus, although the host is still contagious during this time. Perhaps the most infamous exemplification of this process occurred when Magic Johnson, a global icon at the time, announced his HIV-positive status in 1991. The news shocked the sports world and brought powerful awareness overnight.

(6). Johnson’s choice to go public with his HIV diagnosis was impactful for numerous reasons. In 1991, when Johnson made his announcement, those with HIV were often at the center of condemnation. It was a disease that much of the public believed was limited to marginalized communities and was also thought of as leading to a certain death since there existed no cure for the illness at the time. Johnson, being a high-profile celebrity and beloved sports figure, effectively challenged many people’s notions of HIV in terms of who it can impact. The athlete’s announcement humanized the disease in the eyes of many, leading to discussions surrounding prevention, testing, and treatment becoming much more commonplace. Johnson received significant praise for his decision to publicly announce his diagnosis and continues to advocate for reduced stigma of HIV, demonstrating that it is possible to live a full and healthy life as an HIV-positive individual.

(7). Viruses spread through many different means. They can use a carrier organism such as a mosquito or a fly to invade their next host, or they can travel through the air; or can transfer through direct contact of bodily fluids including blood, saliva, semen, vaginal fluid, sweat, or nasal discharge.

(8). Even though viruses cannot carry out their life cycle without a host, they are still susceptible to the same evolutionary pressures that affect other organisms precisely because they rely on other living organisms. If they are to successfully multiply and spread to new hosts, they must carry genes that allow this to happen. If they house genes that do not allow them to multiply effectively, perhaps killing the host within a few hours, those specific genes will disappear forever. On the other hand, if the viruses’ genes are very successful at keeping the host alive and causing the host to spread its viral offspring, this virus will be successful.

(9). As part of the evolutionary arms race, host bodies busily create antibodies that can detect known viruses and lock them into their outer protein surface, thus preventing them from entering the host’s cells. When a mutation in the protein of the virion occurs, it becomes unrecognizable to the host’s antibodies, and the virus is suddenly successful. It will again be able to quickly multiply while the host’s body is busy trying to recognize the new virus and create the appropriate antibodies.

(10). Viruses can make millions of copies of themselves in seconds, which means that their mutation rate is much higher than in an organism that reproduces much more slowly. However, there is a difference in mutation rates between RNA virions and DNA virions. Viruses with DNA are more stable due to a proofreading check, which they have as part of their reproduction process. These virions use the host cell to check their DNA replication. If there is a mistake in the reproductive process, the host cell is often able to correct it. Therefore, viruses containing DNA do not mutate as frequently as RNA viruses. Two known RNA viruses include the influenza virus and the Human Immunodeficiency Virus, or HIV. As a result, these two viruses are of particular interest to scientists.

(11). When a person receives a vaccination, a small amount of virus is injected into their body, allowing the person’s immune system to create antibodies before they are exposed to the virus from the natural environment. Once they are exposed to the virus, the pre-existing antibodies will be able to quickly recognize and protect the person against the known virus before it can invade. However, RNA viruses such as the influenza virus, which causes the flu, have a high rate of mutation, which means that each year scientists must predict likely mutations in the flu virus to develop an effective vaccination.

(12). There are three types of influenza virus: A, B, and C. Type A influenza virus could infect an array of organisms including humans, pigs, dogs, horses, and birds. Along with the fact that it is an RNA virus, this wide range of hosts means that it has more possibility for mutations. Mutations in influenza virus A are limited to the virus’ surface proteins: hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. You may have heard of the H1N1 strain that caused a pandemic in 2009. The name H1N1 refers to mutations in these two proteins. In contrast, influenza virus types B and C are not able to infect other species, and therefore their mutation rate is much slower.

(13). There are two ways in which these proteins can mutate. The first is by antigenic drift, which refers to mutations in the genetic code as a virus reproduces within a cell. The genetic code of an ancestral virus drifts as it accumulates mutations in its proteins. When scientists develop flu shots, they aim to predict the accumulation of mutations in the coming flu season. Sometimes scientists can predict with some accuracy, and other times they may miss altogether.

(14). The second is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus. Because this strain is so dissimilar from either parent virus, it is difficult for the host’s immune system to detect. If this new virus is successful at reproducing and spreading, it could lead to a pandemic.

(15). Because influenza A can infect different species, it has more opportunities to mutate or recombine and create new strains of the virus. If the pig flu and the human flu enter the same host cell in a bird, they may recombine and create a dramatically different type of influenza strain. If this new strain mutates and spreads in a given organism, it has devastating potential. In 2003, the H5N1 strain, or bird flu, scared many people in that it was drastically different from previous strains. Had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by human immune systems. However, this strain did not spread easily among humans and thus, did not turn into a pandemic.

(16). Human infections of bird flu, or 'avian influenza,' are uncommon. When infections do occur, they usually result from close contact with infected birds, often in highly contaminated areas like chicken farms or wet markets. Symptoms of bird flu in humans can vary widely, including fever, eye irritation, upper respiratory issues like sore throat and cough, as well as headaches, muscle aches, and, in some cases, seizures. Symptoms typically appear around three to five days after the initial infection. Although such an outcome is very rare, bird flu can sometimes be fatal in humans should it lead to pneumonia, severe respiratory distress, or organ failure. It is difficult to ascertain when or if a bird flu would lead to an actual pandemic within the human population. Scientists can only keep track of the disease and research how it spreads and progresses over time.

(17). Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently; and because of the prevalence of mutations, two different types of the virus may be present in the same host cell and recombine, forming a dramatically different strain. The challenge is and has been for some time, the development of a productive vaccine.

question.text: What is the purpose of a virus’ host?

options.label: A.
options.text: It serves as a vessel for the virus to stay alive

options.label: B.
options.text: It allows the virus to carry out its life cycle

options.label: C.
options.text: It provides the virus with cells to infect

options.label: D.
options.text: It allows the virus to carry out recombination of its genetic material

options.label: E.
options.text: It provides nutrients for the virus to survive

correct_answer_text: It allows the virus to carry out its life cycle

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, note that the information requested in the question stem applies to relatively basic information about viruses (the purpose of a virus’ host). Thus, we can presume that such information will be found early in the passage. Indeed, paragraph 2 states: “A virus’s genes consist of either DNA or RNA, protected by a coat of protein that shields its genetic information, as well as aids in detecting the appropriate host cells to invade. Some viruses are surrounded by a lipid membrane, and some are not; those surrounded by a lipid membrane are called an enveloped virus, and those which are not are called a naked virus. Naked virus parasites do not have enzymes to carry out their own chemical reactions and are thus completely dependent on a host to make copies of themselves; such hosts include plants, bacteria, archaea, and animals.” This tells us that certain types of virus parasites require a host to make copies of themselves and thus carry out their lifecycle. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. It serves as a vessel for the virus to stay alive – is incorrect because in paragraph 2, the author states: “As these viruses don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their own functions, they have the advantage of being able to lie dormant for years, waiting on a host cell to aid in their reproduction.” This means that viruses don’t need a host to stay alive. Option C. It provides the virus with cells to infect – is incorrect because in paragraph 2, the author says that “….viruses don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their own functions …” This implies that viruses need the machinery of their host to reproduce, not that they need the hosts’ cells. Option D. It allows the virus to carry out recombination of its genetic material – is incorrect because, while this is true of the lysogenic cycle, the host doesn’t just provide the virus a way to recombine its genetic material. Furthermore, according to paragraph 2: “…as viruses don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their own functions, they have the advantage of being able to lie dormant for years, waiting on a host cell to aid in their reproduction.” Option E. It provides nutrients for the virus to survive – is incorrect because in paragraph 2, the author says that “…as viruses don’t have the biochemical machinery to carry out their functions…” This implies that viruses need to use the machinery of the host to reproduce, not that they need the hosts’ nutrients.

question.text: Each of the following can be infected by a virus EXCEPT one. Which is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: Large mammals

options.label: B.
options.text: Volcanic archaea

options.label: C.
options.text: Tropical plants

options.label: D.
options.text: Other viruses

options.label: E.
options.text: Gastric bacteria

correct_answer_text: Other viruses

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, note that the information requested in the question stem applies to relatively basic information about viruses (what entities can be infected by a virus). Thus, we can presume that such information will be found early in the passage. Indeed, paragraph 2 reads: “…hosts include plants , bacteria , archaea , and animals .” The only answer choice NOT listed in paragraph 2 is other viruses . Viruses are not living organisms. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Large mammals – is incorrect because large mammals are animals that are mentioned to be a potential host in the second paragraph. Option B. Volcanic archaea – is incorrect because archaea are mentioned to be a potential host in the second paragraph. Option C. Tropical plants – is incorrect because plants are mentioned to be a potential host in the second paragraph. Option E. Gastric bacteria – is incorrect because bacteria are mentioned to be a potential host in the second paragraph.

When scientists develop flu shots, they aim to predict the accumulation of mutations in the coming flu season. Sometimes scientists can predict with some accuracy, and other times they may miss altogether.

(14). The second is by antigenic shift, which refers to the process where two types of virions enter a host cell and then recombine, creating a new and very different strain of the virus. Because this strain is so dissimilar from either parent virus, it is difficult for the host’s immune system to detect. If this new virus is successful at reproducing and spreading, it could lead to a pandemic.

(15). Because influenza A can infect different species, it has more opportunities to mutate or recombine and create new strains of the virus. If the pig flu and the human flu enter the same host cell in a bird, they may recombine and create a dramatically different type of influenza strain. If this new strain mutates and spreads in a given organism, it has devastating potential. In 2003, the H5N1 strain, or bird flu, scared many people in that it was drastically different from previous strains. Had it been successful at spreading, it would not have been recognized by human immune systems. However, this strain did not spread easily among humans and thus, did not turn into a pandemic.

(16). Human infections of bird flu, or 'avian influenza,' are uncommon. When infections do occur, they usually result from close contact with infected birds, often in highly contaminated areas like chicken farms or wet markets. Symptoms of bird flu in humans can vary widely, including fever, eye irritation, upper respiratory issues like sore throat and cough, as well as headaches, muscle aches, and, in some cases, seizures. Symptoms typically appear around three to five days after the initial infection. Although such an outcome is very rare, bird flu can sometimes be fatal in humans should it lead to pneumonia, severe respiratory distress, or organ failure. It is difficult to ascertain when or if a bird flu would lead to an actual pandemic within the human population. Scientists can only keep track of the disease and research how it spreads and progresses over time.

(17). Another RNA virus with unique properties is HIV. It is capable of producing copies quicker than other viruses, sometimes making more than a billion copies in a day. Because of its quick multiplication, mutations occur frequently; and because of the prevalence of mutations, two different types of the virus may be present in the same host cell and recombine, forming a dramatically different strain. The challenge is and has been for some time, the development of a productive vaccine.

question.text: According to the passage, to what does the term “budding” refer?

options.label: A.
options.text: The reduction of the body’s metabolic processes

options.label: B.
options.text: Virions pinching out of a cell membrane

options.label: C.
options.text: The protein shell in which a virion is encased

options.label: D.
options.text: The rate at which viruses mutate

correct_answer_text: Virions pinching out of a cell membrane

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should search for the first or only instance of the word “budding” in the passage. It can be presumed that a description of this word will follow its initial or only mention. Budding is mentioned only once, in paragraph 3: “Next, they break free either by lysis, which refers to the destruction of the cell, or by budding , in which the new virions pinch out of the cell membrane, carrying a piece of the existing membrane with them. Now that there are more virions, they can spread and continue through a new lytic cycle.” This tells us that “budding” refers to virions pinching out a cell membrane. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. The reduction of the body’s metabolic process – is incorrect because this is part of the body’s immune response and is not called budding, according to paragraph 4: “As the virions multiply and spread, the body’s immune response is often triggered and produces pyrogens; this causes the body’s temperature to rise, inducing a fever, which in turn causes metabolic processes in the body to slow down.” Option C. The protein shell in which a virion is encased – is incorrect because, while paragraph 2 does state that virions are wrapped in a coat of protein, this is not called budding. “A virion is a virus particle consisting of genetic instructions wrapped in a coat of protein. A virus’s genes consist of either DNA or RNA, protected by a coat of protein that shields its genetic information, as well as aids in detecting the appropriate host cells to invade.” Option D. The rate at which viruses mutate – is incorrect because the speed of viral mutation is discussed in paragraph 9, but it is not called budding: “Viruses can make millions of copies of themselves within seconds, meaning that their mutation rate is much higher than in an organism with a much slower rate of reproduction.”

passage.title: Passage 2
passage.text:
(1). Every 5 seconds, one person dies of cardiovascular disease and another two come down with a stroke. The World Health Organization recently reported that ischemic heart disease and stroke are the two leading causes of death and disability worldwide. Death due to heart conditions are most prominent in the United States, where 23% of total deaths are attributed to heart issues. One possible explanation for such a high prevalence of heart disease is an unhealthy lifestyle. Cardiovascular complications are a manifestation of both genetic and lifestyle factors, a concoction of nature and nurture.

(2). Cardiovascular disease results from atherosclerosis – the hardening of coronary arteries leading to irregular blood flow to the heart and the rest of the body. Lipids, cholesterol, and dead white blood cells co-agglutinate to form plaque in the arterial wall and decrease the radius of the vessel. In the face of increased resistance, the blood must flow with more force which leads to increased blood pressure, or hypertension. Hypertension requires the heart to pump harder. A prolonged increase in pumping power causes the heart to grow in muscle mass. The accumulation of muscle in the heart is called hypertrophy, and it makes the heart pump less efficiently. In atherosclerosis, the partially blocked vessel also reduces the delivery of blood and its vital constituents to the heart. Insufficient oxygen delivery induces a hypoxic environment where cardiac cells become strained. Subsequently, the diminished capacity of the heart endangers other organs of the body. The most worrying situation is when the brain is affected.

(3). As the heart drops in pumping power and blood flow slows, clotting ingredients have more opportunity to interact. The frequent interaction of platelets, clotting factors, and fibrin results in more clots. The most stubborn of these clots travel up the carotid arteries that feed blood to the brain and lodge into a narrow vessel. The blockage of this vessel leads to a phenomenon called ischemia, the inadequate supply of oxygen to an organ or group of cells. An ischemic stroke results from the barricade of a major blood vessel by a clot, lowering blood supply to brain cells. Since the brain tissue lacks pain receptors, the symptoms of a stroke are instead identified by cognitive and physical malfunctions. Therefore, a droopy face, imbalanced arms, and slurred speech are used as primary indicators of a stroke. Strokes are particularly malicious as they often involve damage to brain cells, which often cannot recover from any damage, thus necessitating fast treatment.

(4). There are two main treatment options for an ischemic stroke. The first is tissue plasminogen activator (TPA) which is administered via intravenous fluid to break down the clot. Ideally, TPA is given within 4.5 hours of the initial onset of stroke, and it can restore blood flow to critical brain regions and prevent severe cognitive impairment. However, this method fails when confronted with a large clot. In this case, prompt surgical intervention in the form of endovascular thrombectomy would be required promptly to remove the clot. Once the precise location of the clot is located through a fluorescent dye and contrast imaging, a thin catheter is inserted from the ankle and guided to the spot of the blockage where it extracts the clot. Although the brain can be rescued from an ischemic stroke by decisive intervention, a malfunctioning heart is still portentous.

(5). The plaques that reside in the coronary artery walls become more troublesome over time. The turbulent blood flow in partially blocked vessels can rupture the plaque. The broken off portion of this debris, called the thrombus, can initiate another plaque some distance away. Even worse, the newly exposed surface of the original plaque is highly thrombogenic. Thus, as blood cells arrive and agglutinate to the vacant spot, the plaque grows to a point where it might completely impede the flow of blood to cardiac cells and initiate heart failure.

(6). Heart failure describes a gradual process where cardiac cells begin to die off one by one. The heart has not stopped beating at this point but its ability to pump blood progressively declines due to fewer functional muscle cells. The longer an ischemic event persists, the more severe the heart failure becomes. Once the death of cardiac muscle cells reaches a threshold level, chest pain emerges as one of the earliest indicators of a myocardial infarction or heart attack. Often severe heart attacks caused by arterial blockage can be resolved by angioplasty. This is a surgery where a metal stent that looks like a wiry mesh is inserted into the hardened region of the artery to artificially increase its radius and ease stress on the heart. If a heart attack is not identified in due time, the person’s condition continues to deteriorate. Cardiac arrest occurs when the heart ceases to pump. Once this happens, the rule of thumb is that a 3-minute window separates life and death. The death of heart cells to the point of cardiac arrest is irrevocable and the person would require a heart transplant to live.

(7). It is abundantly clear that cardiac health must be a priority for us all. The process of taking care of one’s heart begins with identifying inborn dispositions. Part of the risk for heart attack depends on the non-modifiable factors of age, gender, and genetics. Older people have a higher tendency to develop plaque within their cardiovascular system because of the cumulative effects of their lifestyle. Keep in mind that by upholding a healthy lifestyle that includes exercise for example, some seniors may circumvent the harmful effects of plaque buildup. Moreover, males experience cardiovascular heart disease earlier and more frequently than women. The body of Research hints that the reason is that men adapt unhealthy coping habits when facing stress. Men are more likely to resort to smoking, alcohol, or unhealthy foods when it comes to dealing with anguish. The inability to accept and cope with one’s emotional turmoil has hazardous physical consequences. It has been proven once again that the advocacy for mental health also affects physical health.

(8). Despite setting the hard limits of our cardiovascular health, the massive role of environmental factors cannot be ignored. The Canadian Heart and Stroke Foundation maintains that 80% of heart and stroke diseases are preventable by adopting a balanced diet and a physically active lifestyle. A diet high in fruits and vegetables, legumes, nuts, reduced-fat dairy products, whole grains, and fish is especially recommended. The effect is seen in improved cholesterol levels, lower blood pressure, manageable body weight, and reduced blood sugar. Augmenting such a diet with decreased sodium and saturated fats accentuates the benefits. Furthermore, at least 150 minutes of moderate to vigorous exercise like raking the leaves, dancing, or playing sports when added to moderate alcohol consumption and tobacco cessation leads to reduced blood pressure and cholesterol. Not only that, but exercise takes care of other risk factors for heart disease by producing better sleep, lower levels of stress, and anti-aging effects. In general, the risk factors that are most associated with heart attack include a sedentary lifestyle, poor diet, chronic stress, smoking, alcohol abuse, obesity, and both types of diabetes.

(9). Genetics determines virtually every aspect of the cardiovascular blueprint, from the peculiar shape of capillaries to how the electrical signals are communicated to establish a rhythmic heart rate. If a mutation occurs in a key regulator of cardiac health, it will make a noticeable difference in the prognosis of heart disease. For example, a loss-of-function mutation in the enzyme that processes cholesterol would make it easier for such people to have blocked arteries. But as is the case for many physical ailments, our mind has the power to overcome matter. By employing discipline in everyday choices, you can reap the immeasurable rewards of a healthy heart.

question.text: Out of a group of 200 people at risk of heart disease due to sedentary lifestyles and diets of fast-food, how many can be rescued by introducing exercise and balanced eating into their lifestyle?

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 8 states: “The Canadian Heart and Stroke Foundation maintains that 80% of heart and stroke diseases are preventable by adopting a balanced diet and a physically active lifestyle.” 80% of 200 is equivalent to 160 ; if 10% of 200 is 20, then 8*20 = 160. Therefore, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 40 – is incorrect because 40 out of 200 is equal to 20% which is inconsistent with the 80% statistic given by the Heart and Stroke Foundation. Option B. 80 – is incorrect because 80 out of 200 is equal to 40%, which is inconsistent with the 80% statistic given by the Heart and Stroke Foundation. Option C. 100 – is incorrect because 100 out of 200 is equal to 50%, which is inconsistent with the 80% statistic given by the Heart and Stroke Foundation. Option D. 120 – is incorrect because 120 out of 200 is equal to 60%, which is inconsistent with the 80% statistic given by the Heart and Stroke Foundation.

question.text: Which of the following would be classified as a non-modifiable risk factor for heart disease?

options.label: A.
options.text: Alcohol consumption

options.label: B.
options.text: Smoking

options.label: C.
options.text: Genetic heart defect

options.label: D.
options.text: Sedentary lifestyle

options.label: E.
options.text: Obesity

correct_answer_text: Genetic heart defect

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 7 states: “Part of the risk for heart attack depends on the non-modifiable factors of age, gender, and genetics.” The only answer that describes a non-modifiable factor is option C. This option describes a child born with a natural heart defect, which is permanent and will not go away with the child’s life choices. All other answer options describe things that can be changed with a person’s actions. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Alcohol consumption – is incorrect because alcohol consumption is a lifestyle that can be voluntarily changed, so it is modifiable. Option B. Smoking – is incorrect because smoking is a voluntary action and one can choose to quit if necessary. Option D. Sedentary lifestyle – is incorrect because a sedentary lifestyle describes a lifestyle that is highly inactive and implies other unhealthy choices in diet and other habits. However, this can be fixed by making lifestyle changes to be more active. Option E. Obesity – is incorrect because obesity is the consequence of poor diet and sedentary lifestyle. These factors are largely modifiable as one can make conscious efforts to change them.

question.text: Which of the following explains how hypertension increases risk of heart failure?

options.label: A.
options.text: Reduced blood flow to vital organs

options.label: B.
options.text: Reduced action of blood clotting factors

options.label: C.
options.text: Hypertrophy of heart muscles

options.label: D.
options.text: Plaque accumulation in coronary arteries

options.label: E.
options.text: Decreased resistance in blood vessels

correct_answer_text: Hypertrophy of heart muscles

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 2 states: “A prolonged increase in pumping power causes the heart to grow in muscle mass. The accumulation of muscle in the heart is called hypertrophy , and it makes the heart pump less efficiently.” Option C corresponds to this exact situation because it describes how hypertension makes the heart more muscular and less effective. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Reduced blood flow to vital organs – is incorrect because reduced blood flow to organs, otherwise identified as ischemia in the passage, is caused by reduced heart efficiency. This is in turn caused by hypertension. Thus, this option describes a cause of hypertension, not a consequence of hypertension. Option B. Reduced action of blood clotting factors – is incorrect because in paragraph 3, the passage states that hypertension causes reduced heart efficiency, which gives clotting ingredients more time to interact. Thus, this option is not factually correct. Option D. Plaque accumulation in coronary arteries – is incorrect because in paragraph 2, the author describes how plaque buildup increases resistance in blood vessels, which then leads to hypertension. This option is describing the cause of hypertension, not a consequence of hypertension. Option E. Decreased resistance in blood vessels – is incorrect because paragraph 2 states “In the face of increased resistance, the blood must flow with more force which leads to increased blood pressure, or hypertension.” Thus, similar to option D, increased vessel resistance causes hypertension, not the other way around.

The broken off portion of this debris, called the thrombus, can initiate another plaque some distance away. Even worse, the newly exposed surface of the original plaque is highly thrombogenic. Thus, as blood cells arrive and agglutinate to the vacant spot, the plaque grows to a point where it might completely impede the flow of blood to cardiac cells and initiate heart failure.

(6). Heart failure describes a gradual process where cardiac cells begin to die off one by one. The heart has not stopped beating at this point but its ability to pump blood progressively declines due to fewer functional muscle cells. The longer an ischemic event persists, the more severe the heart failure becomes. Once the death of cardiac muscle cells reaches a threshold level, chest pain emerges as one of the earliest indicators of a myocardial infarction or heart attack. Often severe heart attacks caused by arterial blockage can be resolved by angioplasty. This is a surgery where a metal stent that looks like a wiry mesh is inserted into the hardened region of the artery to artificially increase its radius and ease stress on the heart. If a heart attack is not identified in due time, the person’s condition continues to deteriorate. Cardiac arrest occurs when the heart ceases to pump. Once this happens, the rule of thumb is that a 3-minute window separates life and death. The death of heart cells to the point of cardiac arrest is irrevocable and the person would require a heart transplant to live.

(7). It is abundantly clear that cardiac health must be a priority for us all. The process of taking care of one’s heart begins with identifying inborn dispositions. Part of the risk for heart attack depends on the non-modifiable factors of age, gender, and genetics. Older people have a higher tendency to develop plaque within their cardiovascular system because of the cumulative effects of their lifestyle. Keep in mind that by upholding a healthy lifestyle that includes exercise for example, some seniors may circumvent the harmful effects of plaque buildup. Moreover, males experience cardiovascular heart disease earlier and more frequently than women. The body of Research hints that the reason is that men adapt unhealthy coping habits when facing stress. Men are more likely to resort to smoking, alcohol, or unhealthy foods when it comes to dealing with anguish. The inability to accept and cope with one’s emotional turmoil has hazardous physical consequences. It has been proven once again that the advocacy for mental health also affects physical health.

(8). Despite setting the hard limits of our cardiovascular health, the massive role of environmental factors cannot be ignored. The Canadian Heart and Stroke Foundation maintains that 80% of heart and stroke diseases are preventable by adopting a balanced diet and a physically active lifestyle. A diet high in fruits and vegetables, legumes, nuts, reduced-fat dairy products, whole grains, and fish is especially recommended. The effect is seen in improved cholesterol levels, lower blood pressure, manageable body weight, and reduced blood sugar. Augmenting such a diet with decreased sodium and saturated fats accentuates the benefits. Furthermore, at least 150 minutes of moderate to vigorous exercise like raking the leaves, dancing, or playing sports when added to moderate alcohol consumption and tobacco cessation leads to reduced blood pressure and cholesterol. Not only that, but exercise takes care of other risk factors for heart disease by producing better sleep, lower levels of stress, and anti-aging effects. In general, the risk factors that are most associated with heart attack include a sedentary lifestyle, poor diet, chronic stress, smoking, alcohol abuse, obesity, and both types of diabetes.

(9). Genetics determines virtually every aspect of the cardiovascular blueprint, from the peculiar shape of capillaries to how the electrical signals are communicated to establish a rhythmic heart rate. If a mutation occurs in a key regulator of cardiac health, it will make a noticeable difference in the prognosis of heart disease. For example, a loss-of-function mutation in the enzyme that processes cholesterol would make it easier for such people to have blocked arteries. But as is the case for many physical ailments, our mind has the power to overcome matter. By employing discipline in everyday choices, you can reap the immeasurable rewards of a healthy heart.

options.label: A.
options.text: Fish, vegetable-rich, dairy-rich

options.label: B.
options.text: Red meat, french fries, soda

options.label: C.
options.text: Fish, nuts, seeds

options.label: D.
options.text: Vegetable soups, nut bars, water

options.label: E.
options.text: White meat, high-dairy, legumes

correct_answer_text: Red meat, french fries, soda

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 8 lists the constituents of a healthy diet: “A diet high in fruits and vegetables, legumes, nuts, reduced-fat dairy products, whole grains, and fish is especially recommended. The effect is seen in improved cholesterol levels, lower blood pressure, manageable body weight, and reduced blood sugar.” The worst diet would be expected to lack the foods mentioned by the author. The best option for this is Option B, as every other option has at least one food group that the author identifies as healthy. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Fish, vegetable-rich, dairy-rich – is incorrect because according to the author’s description, fish, vegetables, and dairy are all healthy foods. Option C. Fish, nuts, seeds – is incorrect because according to the author’s description, fish and nuts are all healthy foods. Option D. Vegetable soups, nut bars, water – is incorrect because according to the author’s description, vegetables and nuts are healthy. Option E. White meat, high-dairy, legumes – is incorrect because according to the author’s description, dairy and legumes are healthy.

passage.title: Passage 2

Cardiovascular complications are a manifestation of both genetic and lifestyle factors, a concoction of nature and nurture.

(2). Cardiovascular disease results from atherosclerosis – the hardening of coronary arteries leading to irregular blood flow to the heart and the rest of the body. Lipids, cholesterol, and dead white blood cells co-agglutinate to form plaque in the arterial wall and decrease the radius of the vessel. In the face of increased resistance, the blood must flow with more force which leads to increased blood pressure, or hypertension. Hypertension requires the heart to pump harder. A prolonged increase in pumping power causes the heart to grow in muscle mass. The accumulation of muscle in the heart is called hypertrophy, and it makes the heart pump less efficiently. In atherosclerosis, the partially blocked vessel also reduces the delivery of blood and its vital constituents to the heart. Insufficient oxygen delivery induces a hypoxic environment where cardiac cells become strained. Subsequently, the diminished capacity of the heart endangers other organs of the body. The most worrying situation is when the brain is affected.

(3). As the heart drops in pumping power and blood flow slows, clotting ingredients have more opportunity to interact. The frequent interaction of platelets, clotting factors, and fibrin results in more clots. The most stubborn of these clots travel up the carotid arteries that feed blood to the brain and lodge into a narrow vessel. question.text: More muscular hearts are more prone to plaque blockages because clotting ingredients have more time to interact.

options.label: A.
options.text: Both the statement and the reason are correct and related

options.label: B.
options.text: Both the statement and the reason are correct but NOT related

options.label: C.
options.text: The statement is correct but the reason is NOT

options.label: D.
options.text: The statement is NOT correct, but the reason is correct

options.label: E.
options.text: NEITHER the statement NOR the reason are correct

correct_answer_text: Both the statement and the reason are correct and related

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, one should identify the statement and the reason. The statement is supported by paragraph 2 and paragraph 3. The reason is also supported by the quote from paragraph 3. (2) “A prolonged increase in pumping power causes the heart to grow in muscle mass. The accumulation of muscle in the heart is called hypertrophy, and it makes the heart pump less efficiently.” (3) “As the heart drops in pumping power and blood flow slows, clotting ingredients have more opportunity to interact. The frequent interaction of platelets, clotting factors, and fibrin results in more clots.” These quotes imply that muscular hearts are less efficient, which leads to slower blood flow that causes more clots. Thus, the statement and reason are both correct and related. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Both the statement and the reason are correct but NOT related – is incorrect because the statement and reason are related as more clotting interactions explain why a muscular and inefficient heart is prone to blockage. Option C. The statement is correct but the reason is NOT – is incorrect because the reason is correct in that muscular hearts do give clotting ingredients more time to interact. Option D. The statement is NOT correct, but the reason is correct – is incorrect because the statement is correct in that muscular hearts are more prone to blockages. Option E. NEITHER the statement NOR the reason are correct – is incorrect because this option says neither the statement nor reason are correct, but they are both correct.

question.text: Which of the following combinations most readily results in atherosclerotic plaque?

options.label: A.
options.text: Decreased blood flow and high LDL cholesterol

options.label: B.
options.text: Increased blood flow, platelets, clotting factors, and fibrin

options.label: C.
options.text: Decreased blood flow and ischemia

options.label: D.
options.text: Increased blood flow and platelet factors

options.label: E.
options.text: Decreased blood flow and clotting ingredients

correct_answer_text: Decreased blood flow and clotting ingredients

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 2 states: “Lipids, cholesterol, and dead white blood cells co-agglutinate to form plaque in the arterial wall and decrease the radius of the vessel.” Paragraph 3 states: “As the heart drops in pumping power and blood flow slows, clotting ingredients have more opportunity to interact. The frequent interaction of platelets, clotting factors, and fibrin results in more clots.” Together, the two quotes suggest that plaque forms from a combination of slower blood flow, which gives multiple clotting factors time to interact. Therefore, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Decreased blood flow and high LDL cholesterol – is incorrect because the concept of LDL cholesterol versus HDL cholesterol was not discussed in the passage. Options that are not supported by the passage are not correct. Option B. Increased blood flow, platelets, clotting factors, and fibrin – is incorrect because plaque formation is favored by decreased blood flow which increases the chances of clotting and blockage, but this option mentions increased blood flow. Increased blood flow is not expected to form blockages. Option C. Decreased blood flow and ischemia – is incorrect because ischemia is a result of a blockage in a blood vessel. It is not a component for forming a blockage. Option D. Increased blood flow and platelet factors – is incorrect because this option is mostly correct but it is not as inclusive as possible. Although platelets are involved in clotting as mentioned by the quote in paragraph 3, there are also other ingredients involved that are not mentioned. Thus, this option is not the best answer.

Cardiovascular complications are a manifestation of both genetic and lifestyle factors, a concoction of nature and nurture.

(2). Cardiovascular disease results from atherosclerosis – the hardening of coronary arteries leading to irregular blood flow to the heart and the rest of the body. Lipids, cholesterol, and dead white blood cells co-agglutinate to form plaque in the arterial wall and decrease the radius of the vessel. In the face of increased resistance, the blood must flow with more force which leads to increased blood pressure, or hypertension. Hypertension requires the heart to pump harder. A prolonged increase in pumping power causes the heart to grow in muscle mass. The accumulation of muscle in the heart is called hypertrophy, and it makes the heart pump less efficiently. In atherosclerosis, the partially blocked vessel also reduces the delivery of blood and its vital constituents to the heart. Insufficient oxygen delivery induces a hypoxic environment where cardiac cells become strained. Subsequently, the diminished capacity of the heart endangers other organs of the body. The most worrying situation is when the brain is affected.

(3). As the heart drops in pumping power and blood flow slows, clotting ingredients have more opportunity to interact. The frequent interaction of platelets, clotting factors, and fibrin results in more clots. The most stubborn of these clots travel up the carotid arteries that feed blood to the brain and lodge into a narrow vessel. The blockage of this vessel leads to a phenomenon called ischemia, the inadequate supply of oxygen to an organ or group of cells. An ischemic stroke results from the barricade of a major blood vessel by a clot, lowering blood supply to brain cells. Since the brain tissue lacks pain receptors, the symptoms of a stroke are instead identified by cognitive and physical malfunctions. Therefore, a droopy face, imbalanced arms, and slurred speech are used as primary indicators of a stroke. Strokes are particularly malicious as they often involve damage to brain cells, which often cannot recover from any damage, thus necessitating fast treatment.

(4). There are two main treatment options for an ischemic stroke. The first is tissue plasminogen activator (TPA) which is administered via intravenous fluid to break down the clot. Ideally, TPA is given within 4.5 hours of the initial onset of stroke, and it can restore blood flow to critical brain regions and prevent severe cognitive impairment. However, this method fails when confronted with a large clot. In this case, prompt surgical intervention in the form of endovascular thrombectomy would be required promptly to remove the clot. Once the precise location of the clot is located through a fluorescent dye and contrast imaging, a thin catheter is inserted from the ankle and guided to the spot of the blockage where it extracts the clot. Although the brain can be rescued from an ischemic stroke by decisive intervention, a malfunctioning heart is still portentous.

(5). The plaques that reside in the coronary artery walls become more troublesome over time. The turbulent blood flow in partially blocked vessels can rupture the plaque. The broken off portion of this debris, called the thrombus, can initiate another plaque some distance away. Even worse, the newly exposed surface of the original plaque is highly thrombogenic. Thus, as blood cells arrive and agglutinate to the vacant spot, the plaque grows to a point where it might completely impede the flow of blood to cardiac cells and initiate heart failure.

(6). Heart failure describes a gradual process where cardiac cells begin to die off one by one. The heart has not stopped beating at this point but its ability to pump blood progressively declines due to fewer functional muscle cells. The longer an ischemic event persists, the more severe the heart failure becomes. Once the death of cardiac muscle cells reaches a threshold level, chest pain emerges as one of the earliest indicators of a myocardial infarction or heart attack. Often severe heart attacks caused by arterial blockage can be resolved by angioplasty. This is a surgery where a metal stent that looks like a wiry mesh is inserted into the hardened region of the artery to artificially increase its radius and ease stress on the heart. If a heart attack is not identified in due time, the person’s condition continues to deteriorate. Cardiac arrest occurs when the heart ceases to pump. Once this happens, the rule of thumb is that a 3-minute window separates life and death. The death of heart cells to the point of cardiac arrest is irrevocable and the person would require a heart transplant to live.

(7). It is abundantly clear that cardiac health must be a priority for us all. The process of taking care of one’s heart begins with identifying inborn dispositions. Part of the risk for heart attack depends on the non-modifiable factors of age, gender, and genetics. Older people have a higher tendency to develop plaque within their cardiovascular system because of the cumulative effects of their lifestyle. Keep in mind that by upholding a healthy lifestyle that includes exercise for example, some seniors may circumvent the harmful effects of plaque buildup. Moreover, males experience cardiovascular heart disease earlier and more frequently than women. The body of Research hints that the reason is that men adapt unhealthy coping habits when facing stress. Men are more likely to resort to smoking, alcohol, or unhealthy foods when it comes to dealing with anguish. The inability to accept and cope with one’s emotional turmoil has hazardous physical consequences. It has been proven once again that the advocacy for mental health also affects physical health.

(8). Despite setting the hard limits of our cardiovascular health, the massive role of environmental factors cannot be ignored. The Canadian Heart and Stroke Foundation maintains that 80% of heart and stroke diseases are preventable by adopting a balanced diet and a physically active lifestyle. A diet high in fruits and vegetables, legumes, nuts, reduced-fat dairy products, whole grains, and fish is especially recommended. The effect is seen in improved cholesterol levels, lower blood pressure, manageable body weight, and reduced blood sugar. Augmenting such a diet with decreased sodium and saturated fats accentuates the benefits. Furthermore, at least 150 minutes of moderate to vigorous exercise like raking the leaves, dancing, or playing sports when added to moderate alcohol consumption and tobacco cessation leads to reduced blood pressure and cholesterol. Not only that, but exercise takes care of other risk factors for heart disease by producing better sleep, lower levels of stress, and anti-aging effects. In general, the risk factors that are most associated with heart attack include a sedentary lifestyle, poor diet, chronic stress, smoking, alcohol abuse, obesity, and both types of diabetes.

(9). Genetics determines virtually every aspect of the cardiovascular blueprint, from the peculiar shape of capillaries to how the electrical signals are communicated to establish a rhythmic heart rate. If a mutation occurs in a key regulator of cardiac health, it will make a noticeable difference in the prognosis of heart disease. For example, a loss-of-function mutation in the enzyme that processes cholesterol would make it easier for such people to have blocked arteries. But as is the case for many physical ailments, our mind has the power to overcome matter. By employing discipline in everyday choices, you can reap the immeasurable rewards of a healthy heart.

question.text: Which of the following, if proven true, would most strengthen the author’s view on the vulnerability of the brain?

options.label: A.
options.text: Sustained lack of oxygen leads to the irreparable death of brain cells

options.label: B.
options.text: The formation of new brain cells can be achieved through exercise

options.label: C.
options.text: Endovascular thrombectomy is developing into a more effective treatment

options.label: D.
options.text: Intravenous therapy modalities for stroke can be administered at home

options.label: E.
options.text: Immediate medical attention in the hospital is the only way to handle a stroke

correct_answer_text: Sustained lack of oxygen leads to the irreparable death of brain cells

explanation.concept_text: The question asks which option most strengthens the author’s stance on the brain’s vulnerability. The author’s stance is identified in paragraph 3: “Strokes are particularly malicious as they often involve damage to brain cells, which often cannot recover from any damage, thus necessitating fast treatment.” The author believes that brain cells are vulnerable because any damage they suffer is often irreversible. The only option that supports this view is Option A, as it confirms how brain cells die quickly and cannot be regenerated. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. The formation of new brain cells can be achieved through exercise – is incorrect because this option implies that there are easily accessible ways of regenerating brain cells, which undermines the view that brain cells are irreplaceable. Option C. Endovascular thrombectomy is developing into a more effective treatment – is incorrect because endovascular thrombectomy is a surgical intervention for strokes. If it were more effective, then there is lower risk of damage to brain cells, which undermines the author’s view that the brain is vulnerable. Option D. Intravenous therapy modalities for stroke can be administered at home – is incorrect because the existence of self-administered therapies would make strokes less of an issue. Individuals would be less likely to have a stroke and suffering damage to brain cells. This suggests that brain damage is unlikely, which opposes the author’s perspective. Option E. Immediate medical attention in the hospital is the only way to treat a stroke – is incorrect because although this option suggests that strokes are dire enough to require hospital access, it is not as strong as option A in portraying the brain’s fragility. Option E implies there are still many treatment options available if given professional facilities.
